This time travel thing is a complete mess in the Endgame. I think that Endgame was only for promoting Disney + platform and nothing else. How else can you explain so much screen time for Hawkeye?
Some thing that really bothered me were:
Strong Thanos. Thanos without any infinity stone was much stronger than in Infinity War with 5 stones.Nebula. Why didn't "good" Nebula warned Black Widow and Hawkeye that one of them won't come back when they will get "red stone" ?Steve Rogers. OMG what was with that ending? So basically Steve Rogers married Peggy, watched how Hydra took over SHIELD, his BEST friend was captured and torched for 70years but didn't do anything, because he married the lady he fell in love and knowing her like for two weeks.End of an era? What era? Chris Evans and Robert Downey Junior are done but everything else goes on.Endgame is the most overated movie ever. Period.
The story line was mostly boring, the characters (banner and Thor) were embarrassing and I missed the funny dialogues.
Absolutely littered with plot holes, this the last Jedi of this franchise. Don't let the nostalgic factor blind you from the poor writing.

Endgame wraps up the decade of MCU nicely. A little too nicely. Too many loose ends tied up without any explanation, while tracking through all the movies so far. All the characters from 21 films showed up, even some cameos. Hell, even Natalie Portman showed up! But was that necessary??But the problem in the end was the amount of time spent wallowing in sorrow, which meant that all that brilliant cast of heroes were short-changed, when the time came for them to step up. Doctor Strange brought everyone back and then barely did anything, Black Panther ran for 5 seconds, Shuri was right of frame for all of 5 seconds, Winter Soldier took a couple of shots, I could go on...The emotional moments were not emotional enough, especially Tony's death. Spidey's fade in Infinity War was heart-breaking, Tony's death barely registered. Natasha sobbed for a few frames and then sacrificed herself, quickly forgotten 30 seconds later. I would have been fine with Cap dying in the battle against Thanos, because his life was suddenly made selfish at the end. Which is completely ridiculous, after building that legacy all through these movies.In the end, had it not been for Cap, I would have scored this movie a 5. Him picking up Mjolnir was just pure gold

First of all,the movie is not the the best movie ever unlike some of the reviews telling here,they are marvel shills,don't listen to them, it is not even the best MCU movie.There are a lot of flaws.First thing to discuss the plot,that is stupid,because if Thanos of 2014 comes in 2023 ,then that Thanos never comes in 2018,because he gets killed,infinity war never happens,so how is this movie even possible.The second thing and that might be a bit personal but the movie was advertised as the conclusions of the arcs of the original avengers,they nailed the Arc of iron man,but falcon is not Steve Rogers,there is just one captain America and he can never be replaced.They did it to team him up with Bucky because there is a series coming out on Disney+.and then thor leaves his throne and gives it to the most idiotic person in Asgard, Valkyrie.She is a drunkard,she doesn't shows any attributes of a ruler.Worst decision ever.And u know the reason they did this to pair him up with guardians,so they set up a gotg sequel,they set up a web series and they forced captain Marvel down the audience throats.She just arrived a month ago and is the most egoistic person of the entire MCU.her each line of dialogue is filled with ego and cringe but the action scenes are dope.And why does Hawkeye sacrifices Natasha,Bruce should do it because she is the most loved person in banner's life,not of hawkeye.the best one is when captain America lifts Mjolnir,the theatre was filled with roars for a couple of minutes.Overall just a good movie with enough flaws that sinks it in front of its much better prequel.

I'm a big avengers fan, but this movie... This culmination of all Avengers movies was ridiculous! First of all there is a big mismatch how the world turned out to be after 50% of all species disappeared.Then the whole movie tries to build up this emotional atmosphere about how sad it is for everyone and they spent freaking 3 hours doing this! Game of Thrones kind of does the same, but ten times more effectively. The action scenes are nice, but a kind of a celebration of the characters instead of story line fighting.My review in short. This move is about 90min too long. Cut the slow building emotions scenes, because they are done wrong and only makes you bored. If you wanna know how to do such scenes right look to GoT.

I remember ten years ago when I was a comic book fan and the whispers that were coming out about a Thanos Avengers movie blew my mind. Infinity War satisfied that desire greatly, but Endgame is a mixed bag. I came out of the cinema feeling rather underwhelmed.To be sure, the action is superb. The last half hour of action made me grin from ear to ear and it gave me a similar feeling to watching Return of the King for the first time. However, it was a long road to get to that point.The film is too long. Far too long. It carries far too much baggage from the last movie and drags its heels, which in turn creates a jarring tonal discordance from quipping-Marvel fun to apocalyptic moping. Stop telling me how important things are. I know. Show me why they're important.Another problem I have is the story. It never felt like I was watching one. Infinity War was a hectic race against the clock, Endgame felt like I was watching a board meeting of writers and executives discussing how they're going to tie up loose ends. This is a movie that serves a cinematic universe owned by Disney, rather than serving to tell us a story.Without discussing spoilers, the plot is far too convoluted. The all-powerful Infinity Gems created enough plotholes you have to ignore, but adding time travel to the mix compounds this even further. It would be fine if the movie just dismissed these plotholes, but it keeps harping on the precise mechanics of how the time travel works in the MCU over and over, forcing me to think about how it makes no sense over and over. I don't like thinking about plotholes but Endgame just kept reminding me of them. Combined with the length this makes a large amount of the movie rather a chore to sit through.You must think I hate this movie after that, but I don't. The positives are the ones that come with the standard Marvel movie, funny writing, excellent music, effects, acting and likable characters. I'm certainly glad to have seen it, but unlike Infinity War, it wears out it's welcome after the first viewing.
What a waste of a film. The first hour was totallly wasted. Yes there were good bits in it, but a stupid story with a boring script couldn't save this.

What it needs to be a hero? Power? No. Sacrifice? Yes. It's not the end. There will always be a fight worth fighting for. There will always be a dream to avenge. Never ever give up. Do whatever it takes. And be a hero. Thank you MCU for giving us 10 years of lovely memories. To teach us about love, friendship and determination. It was a wonderful experience, thank you again.

Thoese rating a high score are just not watching the movie at all ."I have to agree with this statement, plot holes all over the movie.. but in the other hand if you like a visual appealing movie and you are a Tony Stark/Iron Man fan well i guess its not a completly waste.In other words, I wouldnt pay to see it again.

I was so, so excited for this. After incredible films like Thor Ragnarok, Captain Marvel and Avengers: Infinity War I thought it would be a sensational ending worth waiting for.It was not.This film could have been 20 minutes long and would have been good, but instead it's stretched out for 3 hours. I have to admit that at many points I found myself thinking 'just get ON with it'There are so many scenes that are so pointless and so drawn out and nowhere near enough action.It's all about that last fight scene, where everyone comes back and Thanos is defeated.
But it's poorly choreographed, badly executed and there's no clear structure to what's going on, there's no bigger picture and the whole thing (although it's my favourite part of the film) just seems badly done.As a woman I'm all up for a bit of girl power, but the bit with all the female characters coming together for a whole 8 seconds then it just focusing on something else was really annoying, it's like they're just trying to tick all the boxes and keep the feminists happy. Just awfulAnd why is Pepper suddenly an Avenger? Hasn't she got a 5 year old to look after?I think I hated it. Which is a shameI don't understand why it has so many good reviews

It has taken many years and lots of work to build up to this amazing movie. This completely satisfied and exceeded my expectations for how I hoped they would pull this all off. I have been a huge fan of the movies leading up to this and this did it all justice. All the hidden "Easter eggs" from the other installments have been hinting towards this and I can't believe how big this has all gotten over the years. I was glad to see that even though this movie had a very serious fight at hand that there was still some classic Marvel comedy that made for some very funny moments. There was laughter, tears, and cheers through this movie. It was an emotional roller coaster that I already plan on going to again soon in theaters. It is a must see for those who have already been fans of the MCU and if you haven't followed it to this point this movie won't make sense or mean much to you so go back and watch the other movies. It is all worth it.

This movie does everything right. I was so pleased and satisfied walking out of the theater, it's really hard to understate it. The Russo Brothers absolutely lived up to the expectations and delivered the epic conclusion we were all waiting for. You can probably nitpick this movie if you want (as you can any movie), but to me that's pretty much what you have to do to find flaw with it. I think that the emotions throughout are played so well and we get those moments with each character where they feel human, especially with all 6 of our original avengers. Each has their moment to shine and I truly loved it. The humor was well-used, the story made sense, the finale was downright perfect, and it was an all-around great movie!SPOILERS
My favorite stuff
The beginning with Clint's family was downright heartbreaking to watch, and a great way to bring that human aspect to the story, seeing someone who had no idea what was going on be affected by the snapThe subversion of expectation meeting thanos and realizing he not only doesn't have the stones but he doesn't carePaul Rudd. What a guy.The second act plot is really done well, it makes sense yet the way they go about it with the callbacks to almost every movie through cameos or reliving scenes is great, especially in the New York scenes (specifically the elevator scene from winter soldier being called back)-Black Widow dying is another expectation subversion and is done very well
Tony having a moment with his dad is great to seeThe way by which thanos is reintroduced as the villain is actually brilliant and gives a new perspective to his motivations and the way he destroys the facility after the reversal snap is greatCap picking up Thor's hammer is all kinds of yupGiving our main three some alone time fighting thanos is a great way to give them their time to shineAvengers Assemble is everything I didn't know I needed.Tony's arc is done so well and how he sacrificed himself reminds me so deeply of the scene in Avengers when cap said tony wouldn't sacrifice himself for others.Cap getting to dance with PeggyThor joins the Guardians!My negative stuff (these didn't really bother me that much but a little bit)
The whole fat Thor thing kinda makes some of the dramatic moments later on kinda weaker in my opinionSame with half-hulk, almost felt hard to take him seriously at first but it made more sense as the story grewNot sure I can buy thanos changing his mind for his plan to cleanse the universe by destroying it and starting over, but I like that he's willing to die for his own causewould've liked more action especially in the first act but I appreciated the emotions

After Infinity War I knew it would be hard to top. And I was certainly correct. This movie has little to no action, and relies heavily on a 'blast from the past' mentality. In a movie where half the population has been wiped out, everyone seems to be pretty happy about and make jokes about it all the time.

I just went to see the Avengers Endgame on Apr 25th, in Hawaii.First, I have to say......it was a good solid movie. However, it did not touch me or speak to me. I was not moved at all. The Infinity Wars, was far more emotional and gut wrenching, this one was just an attempt to change things up, do the unexpected, and try desperately to wrench our emotions.I will simply say that in this movie I was never mad, hurt, sad, or excited. No emotions this time.Some of the battles were epic, and some were hyped up and fizzled out quickly, and some battles just never happened. Some disappointing moments.Finally, when the battle was reaching a climax, and the home team got a chance to exact some revenge, things felt petty and predictable. Honestly, might have been better to follow the comic arc and stay true. Honestly, for the life of me, I do not know why I was not choked up in certain scenes when I should have been. Seems they were trying to hard to touch our hearts, and it felt disconnected.Three hours later......and had to wake my wife up several times which is usually a sign. She was wide awake in Infinity Wars, beginning to end.So if you just looking for revenge or a reckoning, congratulations.....you got it. But if you are looking for real emotional struggles and happy reunions......mehhhhhh......they tried....some were decent.I will not give any spoilers, but I will say I am flat out angry because my favorite character of all time, since I was a child, did not fight! Seriously, WTF?! And after what happened in Infinity Wars, it makes no sense.

I think the time traveling idea was a good one and probably the only option they had for that story line in restoring the worlds population but I think it could have been done a little different perhaps with a little more action. The last 30 mins was a great battle and fairly similar to infinity war and I think it was right to kill off iron man and pretty much kill off captain America (although captain America going back to put the stones back has me questioning more of the time jump)The areas of the film that I really didn't enjoy were the treatment of 2 characters, thor.....fat and a slob!? I understand he felt responsible but his character was turned into a bit of a joke which was awful. Likewise the hulk, not really a man and not really the hulk but somewhere in between.....again I understand he found peace to live with the hulk but it was not done very well in my opinion.Going back to thor he was very close to defeating thanos in infinity war when thanos had stones, yet in end game thanos had no stones and Thor couldn't get close to him!Maybe I need to watch it a second time and like I said it was just a good film with a lot of holes and I couldn't help feel disappointed after the hype and build up.

Endgame has some really fun and epic moments. It also has some very emotional moments. But this movie is far from a "love letter" to fans of the OG6 Avengers, as some critics have claimed. Far from it. Endgame basically steamrolls over 10 years of character development for most of the OG6, especially Tony, Steve, and Thor. I was extremely disappointed with how these characters were treated, because they deserved so much better than Endgame. Instead of resolving their character arcs in a satisfying and sensical way, the Russos decided to go for meaningless shock value and "fanservice" that only makes sense to them (and not the majority of fandom). This is like Age of Ultron all over again, except much more depressing and upsetting. A shameful end to a wonderful saga.

It's a fine action movie for one time, jokes are good too. However, it lacks something that Infinity War had. As anyone else I've been waiting for the greatest hit the entire year. It's sad to admit but I left the theater with a feeling of disatisfaction.

I'm a lifelong Marvel nerd. I live and breathe Marvel; with that said I'll start my review. The story picks up immediately after Infinity War with Thanos decimating 50% of all life as they try and rectify it. The cast was good though I honestly felt it lacking in conviction besides Tony Stark. The action was lackluster as heck. Endgame is 30 minutes longer then Infinity War and had maybe a fourth of the action runtime that its predecessor had prior. Disappointing battles minus one which lasted all of but a few minutes. The comedy was Endgames only saving salvation to be honest. It pains me to write this because Infinity War was the best superhero movie since sliced bread for a culmination movie. Average at best for me. They should have stopped after Infinity War though I know the comics wouldn't have it. I personally thought it was a cash grab. I'd say watch it once absolutely but don't believe the hype. Endgame makes Age of Ultron look good AF.

Warning: This movie will exceed your expectation!!!Marvel has quite mastered the art of story-telling!The trailer has been teasing us with pretty much nothing and what a way to promote Endgame.In the rarity of today's world, where most trailers almost tell you everything in 3 minutes.This review is about to reveal nothing just like the trailer did other than what an epic conclusion!!Tears 7/10

First I would like to remark that it is my very own personal opinion and I don't want to scare anybody from watching this movie. Every MCU fan should watch this film, but as I, a comic fan as well, won't enjoy it as much as one expects it, in my opinion.
I grew up on these films and the crown of those films was unfortunately built merely on the last films for example Captain Marvel.
I don't want to speak about what would be better I better just say what I liked and what I did not.
I liked that the final battle was very comicish, and that this film explained a bunch of previous mysteries for instance how the Hydra got the scepter.
I disliked that the jokes were too childish for me and that the time travel was too sloppy.
I found a bit disrespectful what they did to Thor the god of thunder and I still don't understand why they boosted Captain America to be able to hold the Mjölnir and summon lightnings.
All in all I am a bit disappointed, I feel it is not worth my awaitings and I am a bit concerned what the future of our beloved characters will be.
Was it good? Of course it was.... Was it the best one in the series? Not even close... I was so excited for this movie and I left disappointed.

As others said, the time travel part just stinks. I still enjoyed it, I laughed on the jokes, there were moments where I nearly cried, and others that made me clap with all along the audience. But overall the who whole story is quite an illogical mess. There's the saying "they bit more than they can chew". This is exactly what happened, they tried to fill all their previous movies into one and it could actually work, if they just fixed the time travel part. But they didn't, and I left the theatre with full of unanswered questions. Too bad, because there were so many good ideas, emotions, and great acting.
I don't know. I don't like it much. I think because after infinity war i expected much more from marvel! And i liked infinity war very very much.

I don't know if we ever could of imagined the state of Marvel comic-book movies 11 years after the first MCU film in 2008, to review this film as a movie a one of film, I don't think that would do it justice because as a single stand alone film (even though its a sequel) would not do it the proper justice , however this is the only way I know how to break down a film. I will judge the MCU as a whole in another review. If I was to sum this movie up as brief as possible its, Avengers end game is the fan service movie you didn't know you wanted, with a story and battles thrown in there to pad the run time.
Where the movie succeeds is in its grandeur and its design, it is extremely large scale, sometimes to its own detriment ( I looking at you final battle sequence ) but nevertheless you can feel the immensity of this epic, I will be breaking it down into several parts, Story, Cinematography, Actors/Actress , Characters, Motivations, Soundtrack, Pacing, Design, Re-watch ability & HeartStory
when you have a story that expands over 20 plus movies to culminate into one it is a hard task, but this movie does succeed in the story it has clear goals, which they seem to accomplish, sometimes without any resistance what so ever, the scene where Tony stark, just happens to make time travel possible after stating it could never be done, was a little jarring & every obstacle that they did eventually encounter was immediately remedied, antmans a baby then turn the power off , couldn't get the correct stone, just go back again, there seemed to be obstacles placed in there way in order for the heroes to just step over them, rather then a climb or hurdle, personally I feel it would have been better to have as many if they were not as significant, the part I loved was in the first act where we see a 5 year jump and the world is still in mourning over the vanishing of half the population, the arc in which Hawk eye is introduced again was a satisfying one, the lead up to the inevitable gathering of all the heroes from earth and beyond was something expected in the final act but was done in a way that would even simmer the harshest of critics, the killing of Thanos in the first 10 minutes was a pleasant surprise, but without a clear antagonist until about 1 hour and 45 minute mark, the story progression took a back seat for character development, Storyline Score 7.5/10Cinematography
Thankfully unlike a lot of the other MCU this film sense of Enormity was done quite well with the cinematography, while the standardised shot, reverse shots were very predominant, there are a few glorious moments, mainly involving the quantum realm & the final battle sequence, the colour scenes and lighting are an improvement on Infinity war up until the final battle, but the cold colour pallet sets the mood for a very different MCU film in the beginning , Cinematography Score 6/10Actors/Actress
To me this is where the movie shines its brightest as there is a range we see from many actors, the desperation in the beginning on Chris Hemsworth's face & the slight lip quiver and slightly tearing eyes of Scar-Jo allowed us to see this is a passionate cast we are dealing with, the subtleties of almost every actor in this film reflect the minor changes they have from shot to shot, with a show don't tell style which is refreshing for the MCU. Stand-outs are RDJ, Chris Evens & Scarlet Johansen
Actor/actress score 8.5/10Characters
Every character in this film felt like they had a role to play, and there wasn't too much cross over between them, rocket raccoon was the snippy one, ant-man was the comic relief however Thor was a problem to say the least, the running gag of him being a fat hair drunk was played up way to much and in almost every scene he was in we are constantly reminded that he is drunk and fat and hairy, he was the anti Thor to every other Thor portrayals & it wasn't because of what he went through it was because of how he was written. The characters develop properly in this and while there isn't many major arcs in the film involving characters the one of Tony stark from, being afraid to do anything because of the fear of losing his daughter or his daughter losing him transcending into the hero that defeated Thanos and died in the process, was not only touching but poetic, the sounds of sobbing where heard in the theatres and it was a (forgive the pun) stark reminder of what the characters mean to people here in the real world. Character score 7/10Motivations
Every movie has the characters that motivations make no sense - this film is no different , however as of writing this, I cannot find a world breaking character motivation that took me away from the film, they all had goals and did what they needed to do to achieve those goals. With one of the exception, when evil nebula comes back from the past, everyone seems to forget about her while sorting out the infinity stones, which felt like a plot device to allow her to bring Thanos to the future.
Motivations 9/10Soundtrack
The best part of the score was the nostalgic soundtracks when different characters were introduced and combined with the current score, the music in this film is generic and nothing to write home to, there is a distinct lack of strong motivating soundtrack to pump you up nor one to bring you down when needed, for me this was one of the most disjointing parts of the film .Soundtrack score 3/10Pacing
The film has a pacing issue, go figure a 3 hour movie with a pacing issue, there are scenes and segments where it is clear, this section is for laughing, this section is for going wow, this is the sad section and felt extremely stretched, the first 1 hour and a half was the hardest part to get through pacing wise, when we are so used to a full film being over by this stage, I feel there is many parts of this film that could be cut out to make it more streamline without compromising the final product.
The final act approx 1 hour 10 minutes of the film goes extremely fast while the first 2 acts seem to almost double in length when watching it. Pacing score 5/10Design
There is not much to say about the design of the world they create, everything is as it should be, the time machine looked great and believable, Thanos ships & warriors, every planet (most of which we have seen before) were done almost flawlessly - the only concern I had was the look of Thanos when moved and fought, seemed extremely ridged and choppy, not sure if that is to do with where I watched it on, but it was jarring. Design score 8.5 out of 10Re-watch ability
This is where this part of the review gets tricky, there are parts that are extremely fun and enjoyable to watch over and over again, give me the first 15 minutes and the last hour, but to go through the choppy paced part of the film when you already know what is happening, is a task, a movie like this which has many ups and downs within it, its a journey and one I will not be partaking a 3rd time any time soon. It does take a lot out of you physically and emotionally & reliving those emotional moments tends to make them less of an impact & with those moment this films climax would not stand up. Re-watch ability score 6/10Heart
This movie does have heart, it is the one key factor that I find in more of the grittier comicbook film I tend to enjoy more, there is a joyfulness that is thrown in there in times of stress , undercutting the tension of the film, this is what I call marvel-ing for everything serious you have you must immediately undercut it with something else, normally this is one of my biggest pet peeves about marvel films as of late but for what ever within the confines of this film I felt them more necessary then ever, the characters interaction with each other and the care you can see is not just an act make this movie much more than I expected. Heart score 9/10
Adding the totals I give the film a review of 70.5% Making it the 5th highest aggregate score
That being Said, I did thoroughly enjoy the film and do recommend it.

It wouldve been easily the most epic comic book movie ever. (It still is for many parts)Not gonna go into huge spoilers for this one, just gonna say that the story was brilliant. It was SO well executed.What really annoyed me about this movie were 3 things:
1) Thor being a complete laugh
2) Fortnite (seriously Marvel? thats just sad)
3) Cap being able to wield Thors hammer all of a sudden for no reason at all. (Time travel makes it reconsider whos worthy it seems?)oh and 4 - 14000000) Fortnitehave a good one

* Why buildup Thor only to tear him to shreds in Endgame? You literally destroyed his brand.
* How was Captain Marvel able to locate the ship Tony Stark was on at the beginning of the film?
* Why use "Quantum Realm" when the majority of the audience will get confused and lost in it?
* Why did Captain Marvel say she was going to fight Thanos solo when she, Captain America, Thor, and Iron Man couldn't even take him down without a use of a gauntlet? Is she really that arrogant?
* Why was Thanos awesome in the first movie, but became a generic villain in Endgame?
* Why did the writers do an awesome job on the infinity war, but fall hard in Endgame? Did someone just tell them, "let's put all the jokes and scenes you guys want and hopefully it makes sense." Because that's exactly what it felt like.
* Why doesn't doing anything in the past affect the future? It felt so cringeworthy seeing interactions in previous movies that weren't meant to happen.
* Why has Thor become Batman of the DC universe? Do directors and producers LOVE destroying characters that we love? Seems like it.
* Thor's mother didn't need to be "trained by witches" to know that her son Thor was different from her son she saw only moments earlier. So why even bring that up?
* Did everyone who "died" in infinity war go to a special spirit world of wakanda and just remain there till 5 years later according to spider-man?
* Why couldn't have anyone simply put on the gauntlet and wiped out Thanoses army? And why didn't Thanos destroy everybody who was a threat to him in infinity war?
* Why did a rat start Endgame by returning ant-man? That seems awfully convenient doesn't it?
* How can Captain America pick up Thor's hammer and even use lightning when he couldn't pick it up in the first avengers movie?
* Where was Captain Marvel most of the movie? Was she vacationing?
* Why was the first hour so slow, The second hour and a half talking about quantum physics that no one understands, and the last 30 minutes of the film fighting when anyone could have simply worn the glove and wiped out thanoses army?
* How did Scarlett Witch seemingly become more powerful than even Captain Marvel?
* Why didn't anyone save Black Widow when everything else can be done with convenience? Did no one just not want to save her because there was no purpose and it just gave them rage to fight?There's a hundred more questions I want to ask, but these are just some of the main ones.

Amended after re-watching:
First the good:
1. Big fight scene was epic and was great to see everyone on screen at the same time . Amazing stuff.
2. Favorite part - Cap handles Thor's hammer. Just outstanding and emotional.
Ok, now the not so good:
1. Captain Marvel. Why they make the biggest and baddest superhero someone we haven't grown to love over the previous decade is baffling. And beyond that, Brie Larson is just unlikeable. But seriously, if she could take Thanos on head to head by herself and blow up his ship in seconds, why not let her wear the gauntlet? Lastly, going out of their way to let you know she's a lesbian was a bit much. You don't need a short haircut and ugly clothes just because you're gay. Plenty of attractive lesbians out there, but whatever. Brie butchers the role regardless.
2. Professor Hulk - did anyone like this adaptation? We've grown to love seeing Hulk smash and in both this and Infinity Wars, not one single fight scene with him smashing. Just sad.
3. Fat Thor - ok, fine, Chris Hemsworth can pull off the comedy really well, and I enjoy it when he does, but the whole movie we get the Big Lebowski? I would have much rather seen him back in shape magically from reconnecting with Mjolnir. In the end, he was still extremely awesome, so that was fine, but I just don't see the point of making him fat for the whole movie.
4. Time travel - is anyone besides me sick of every Sci-fi show using time travel to fix everything? If you're going to do it, at least take full advantage. We had the opportunity to see one on one fights with Thanos' Black Squad. How about Hulk going primal against the big guy (and even hurting Thanos some). Dr, Strange rematch with Ebony Maw, etc., etc. on the end, I think they could have cut some of the boring first hour and given us more action fight scenes that we've come to know Marvel for.In closing, the movie was still really good. I guess my expectations were just so high as they were closing out the phase that the changes with Hulk, Thor, and introduction of Captain Marvel just seemed misplaced and took away a lot of what I had come to love about the franchise. Still better than anything DC has managed to throw together.

I enjoyed this as a popcorn movie, but parts of it made no logical sense to me. For example, if Nebula only had one Pim's capsule, how on earth did Thanos AND Gamora AND past Nebula travel to the future? Also, if people are traveling forward on their own timeline (as they suggested) then how can they travel forward to a timeline where they are already dead? Makes no sense.

It was inevitable that Infinity War set up too big a plotline for it to not be somewhat disappointing in the conclusion. Very sentimental (too sentimental?). These will not be popular opinions. Oh well.

Hawkeye loses his family with the snap. Tony Stark and Nebula are stranded in space. They are rescued by Captain Marvel. What remains of the Avengers set off to confront Thanos only to find that he had already destroyed the Stones. Five years later, Scott Lang escapes from the quantum realm. He is shocked by the new world order and comes up with an idea to save everyone, a Time Heist.This is the 22nd film in the MCU. The best aspect is that it pulls together the whole series of movies and fulfill many of their emotional storylines. Iron Man, Thor, Captain America, Black Widow, Hawkeye, Ant-Man, and Nebula all get some powerful personal stories. Thor is doing a funny "The Dude" Lebowski. Iron Man is his family. Captain America finally gets his love. Hawkeye becomes vengeance. There are some other aspects that I would alter with the Infinity Gauntlet.For Ant-Man, Paul Rudd's comedic takes diminishes his pain from losing Hope. He's not quite as broken as Hawkeye. His lost keeps conflicting with his humor. Black Widow's fight with Hawkeye lasts too long. Sometimes, less is more and doing fewer reversals would add power to each turn. Nebula's final confrontation with herself needs some better work. She needs to have a talk with herself or do an Indiana Jones and shot right away. She could give a punchline like "I don't like how she looks". The movie yadayada a lot about time travel. The only explanation is that it's not any of those movies. It's a funny line but it's basically saying that it has no rules. Then the characters say that there are rules. I don't begrudge the MCU for yadayadaing the rules because that could get real complicate. Finally, this MCU ends like many MCU movies, with a chaotic massive final battle. I'd prefer cutting that back and the female Avengers assemble is a little too convenient. Just have two other women. That's enough. It becomes fan service. Overall, the emotional resolutions are great. The recalls to the other movies are satisfying. The story works for the most part. In a franchise that is sure to keep going to infinity, this is a great rest stop to say a few goodbyes.

I had very high expectations for this one because Avengers: Infinity War was indeed a very good movie.Things I didn't like:1) Fat Thor: Thor is my favourite Marvel / Avengers character and I didn't like seeing him being ridiculed like that2,3,4) Iron Man and Nat dying, Captain America ageing: I just didn't like these outcomesOverall I would have preferred an ending where they beat Thanos and just all stay alive and well.

It was an ok movie. I liked it, but I felt it could've been a lot better.For the first half of the movie, things were going along well. It was paced a bit too slowly, as I felt like it could've worked better if it were faster, but it still worked. Some of the comedy was alright, but some things I found unnecessary was the stuff about Hulk dabbing and Thor playing Fortnite.... and him... being fat. Yeah, that honestly was way too cringey.The second half was disappointing, to say the least. Thanos' character was... well... let's just say he was meh and so two-dimensional in comparison to his Infinity War counterpart. And then there was the final clash. That was definitely A LETDOWN. It just felt too rushed, too shallow and bland (almost as bland as all the character's reactions in front of Iron Man's funeral). And there were only a few of the characters in that battle, especially the revived ones who died in Infinity War that actually got a decent amount of screentime and even enough lines (Drax, Mantis, Doctor Strange even, I mean, seriously, they barely said anything).The ending was... ehh. Although it is justifiable for Captain America to spend all that time with Peggy (Thanos has just been defeated, what else could he do now other than fulfilling his long-held desires?), what's weird is that he showed up on the bench as an old man rather than traveling back with his suit, implying that he had lived through one timeline leading up to his future arrival (which literally makes no sense, considering the time-travel rules the movie made for itself).I definitely thought this movie could've played out so much better, but then the script just hits us with plot holes and many unanswered questions (such as what happened to Loki and the tesseract too?) It could've been so much more, but hey. That's just me. I guess all that hype from Infinity War made me disappointed.
This time I m speech less best movie of the year and so emotional comedy and some out of action this is snap of fingers

I just felt like the movie could have been better it they included more scenes with the "resurrected" heroes leading up to the last battle scene...
First 2 hours are kind of dull. I was expecting more frankly. Reckon it's predictable as well, the last hour was entertaining though.

With so many plot holes reshoots cringy and illogical scenes and cutting out 1.5 hours runtime from 4.5 hours you called this cinematic event. Cinematic Event was Infinity War and always will be Infinity War was1000 times better than this crap

The end of an era as fans might say and to which I say "I agree." With that said it was a failed attempt at making history and ending up being garbage. I'll take nothing away from the acting nor the special effects and of course that portal scene. It was absolutely AMAZING!! As for the rest of the movie it was s**t. I can't believe that a rat saved the universe and say what you will about Tony Stark actually "saving" it, but you would be wrong and you are so suck it. Anyways, making Thor fat was a big mistake and ruined the character that just started to become iconic. In the final battle of the movie I was not in my seat with excitement more of dissatisfaction if anything and that is because it was such a one sided battle like seriously I felt they took a page out of Fairy Tail and made everyone that wasn't apart of the Avengers or heroes weak. I "love" the fact that there is only one hero who dies in the battle and it was really pointless because they could have just revived him with the Time Stone. The greatest weapon in the universe was tossed around like a game of Hot Potato what a shame. If nothing else kill Captain America as well as a few other heroes such as War Machine. Yes. Black Widow died, but it was less of a tole because she died the same way as Gamora a year prior and why did she die it should have been Hawkeye. He is such a complete waste of time in the MCU and it's clear that Marvel doesn't see him as a strong character. When you really think about it Black Widow is getting a movie while Hawkeye gets a TV Series. It shows who they like more and Widow it dead. Professor Hulk sucks. Thanks for ruining him Marvel!! The last thing that didn't sit well with me was dissing every single time traveling movie. In conclusion this movie should been a trilogy so that there could have been more built rather than something that felt to rush to the end and start on a new chapter. I like to think that it could have been like "Lord of the Rings" and what that trilogy accomplished and I don't think anyone would have complained about that. This movie is a joke.

In her solo-movie, we learn that she has incredible powers and should be the key to an ending to the war.Then in this movie, she is absent all along and when she shows up, she is suddenly weaker? I couldn't help but recognise that the other male superheroes (who are less powerful than Captain Marvel), as Captain America, get unfairly too much more attention than her.I would say same about Thor, he is literally a god and then this Captain America appear to be stronger???It's pretty clear that the producers favour certain characters.This makes the movie incoherent and a bit nagging.

Every thing is just so balanced.
It was so good that i wanted to rewatch it again after i walked out of the theaters.

Basically, a clip-show. The writing is uncharacteristically sub-par. The whole endeavor is uncharacteristically formulaic. The actors turn in their usual grade-A performances, but deadened by a dead script. Too many elements are gratuitous. If you're new to the franchise, don't judge it by this; if you've been with it for the whole ride--but remain somewhat objective--I'm afraid you might be disappointed.

Reason why I am not disappointed by this movie is because I wasn't expecting much from it in a first place.Infinity war was 'perfectly balanced': action scenes, motivation of characters, humor. Endgame wants to be the same movie, but it simply cannot reach that level.Things I liked:
Humor level is pretty good. It's not overwhelming and there is enough.
Visuals - obviously, action scenes... as well as everything else looks amazing.
Feeling of nostalgia - can't deny, there are tons of references you will find at this movie and it feels amazing to spot every small detail of this universe. (Not gonna work, if you haven't watched majority of marvel movies).Things I am neutral about:
Time travel: the very moment characters started to talk about time travel, I had a bad feeling. Ironically, they even inserted jokes about time travel movies and ultimate phrase: "It's not how time travel works".
After Thanos stated that he "shred stones to atoms" I was expecting they will just use quantum realm to restore the stones without time-travel stuff. However, at the same time it would neglect huge part of Nostalgia, so I'm undecided on this. The major hole of time travel I noticed is ending with old Steve, who spent his life in another timeline (if I understood correctly) and somehow ended up on the bench in the original timeline without using a machine.Things I disliked:
Pace of the movie: It starts really slow, almost boring. And when the main story actually starts to be interesting and intense (which is after 75% of the movie), there is simply no place to insert character interactions I would like to see. Most of the characters, who died in IW has like 5-30 seconds of screen time and only few of them even says a word.To sum up, Avengers: Endgame is not a perfect movie, but it's also not terrible.
Experience from it is truly individual.
If you weren't following marvel movies story-line and characters, or you feel indifferent to them - it will be just an average marvel movie with full bag of stereotypes you love/hate.
In case you liked all previous movies, this - will be no exception.

There are already a surfeit of general reviews for this movie, so I am going to focus on the central conceit of the plot - time travel - and the way it is handled.The time travel device is flagged with the tongue firmly in the cheek, as the characters break the fourth wall to share jokes with the audience about how all our time travel knowledge comes from... movies. Therefore it is not knowledge at all, and we can freely revolutionize our sense of time travel on the fly. Yay!So the old logic of time travel - that you change and endanger the present by messing with the past in any way - is done away with. And a new logic of time travel is introduced: now changing the past in no way affects the present, instead just creating new parallel timelines. Or, to put it as the Avengers' writers do, the 'past' that I visit is actually in my future. It is not even really happening in the past...(?)Thus, to use (and modify appropriately) the old Back To The Future premise, if I go back and tell my past self the outcome of a bunch of sporting events and advise making a bet or two, I will not be one penny richer when I get back to the present, because that is not really my past self. It is my past self from another timeline, one who got rich using a list of sporting results from the future. Get it?I must say that when Avengers:Endgame proposed this premise I was initially very happy with it. Honestly, it makes a hell of a lot more sense than the normal time travel logic, for one simple reason: if there is only one timeline (as in most time travel movies), time traveling to the past and changing it is highly likely to prevent the time travel taking place, certainly in the way that it did in the initial, non-past-changed version of the present.So for instance, if I go back and kill Thanos as a child (as Ant-Man suggests), he never gets the stones, I am never prompted to time travel by him killing half the universe, and the time travel never happens, so who exactly went back to kill Thanos? Certainly not the version of me in the present in which Thanos is dead! When you think about it, there MUST be two timelines: one where Thanos had the stones and, in desperation, I went back in time and killed him; and another where I was chillin', because I never heard of Thanos, because he was dead. Simple, right?Why, then, I hear you cry, did most if not all previous time travel movies not notice and obey the clearly superior logic of time travel - namely that changing the past cannot affect the present - followed by Avengers:Endgame?The answer is fiendishly simple: If time travel creates alternate timelines rather than changing the present, it also creates no possibilities for dramatic jeopardy, because nothing I do in the past makes much difference. And this is true not just for the present, but also for the past. Are you with me? Allow me to explain...Say I go back to the past - not far in the past, just five minutes - and empty my own wallet, which is on the kitchen table (let's say it contains a 20 pound note). I now return to the future with 20 quid in my hand, but when I go to the kitchen and look in my wallet, guess what? The money is still there! I now have forty quid in total, the only caveat being that the two notes have the exact same serial number. Notice how this is a totally zero-sum game. There is only 20 pound for each version of reality, and if one has an extra one, another must be missing one.But suddenly, I feel bad about robbing my past/alternate self of his 20 pound, and decide to go back again, to four minutes in the past, and give my self back the money. But when I get there, guess what? I cannot do it! Because I am going back to my own version of four minutes ago, in which I never lost the 20 quid. All I can do is create a third timeline, which was visited by a friendly version of future me handing out money, in addition to the second timeline which was visited a by a greedy version of future me taking money. (now a three-way zero-sum game)To put it another way. If changing things five minutes ago does not change the present, then it also does not change any point between five minutes ago and the present.Let's take another scenario. I make up a codeword, and then go back to five minutes ago and tell my past self (call him me2) that word, before returning to the present. Once I get back to the present, I can never visit me2 again, because he is no longer in my past. In my past I made up the word just now, but he was told the word five minutes ago by his future self.So if I go back in time and borrow something (an Infinity Stone for instance) I cannot give it back, ever. Because when I next visit the past, it will be my past, not the slightly funky alternative past I spawned last time by borrowing an Infinity Stone.Thus, when Hulk promised the Ancient One that he would be right back with her stone, she would have calmly explained that this was not possible, because by merely appearing in her reality he had forked it off from his own, and the version of the past he returned to next time would feature a new her, complete with stone, and with no memory of meeting him.In other words, if changing the past does not change the present, then the past resets itself every time I travel back in time. In every way.The problem (from dramatic perspective) is, this makes the past a very boring place. I can go back and kill someone (even myself) a million times, but every time I come back they will be alive and well, totally clueless about the many deaths they have suffered at my hands. It also almost makes the present like a computer game cheat mode, because I can double my resources anytime by just going back one minute and robbing myself!The movie tried to get around this by making time travel dependent on a finite number of Pym particles, but the exact same logic applies here. You can go back five minutes and rob yourself of all your Pym particles as many times as you like. Sure those timelines are now not going to be able to stop Thanos, but ultimately, what does it matter? There are already, according to this logic of time travel, infinite timelines where Thanos wins, and infinite timelines where Thanos loses, and none of them matter to you at all. Maybe those suckers you robbed in the past are better off without their Pym particles? You will never know or have any way of finding out.Clearly this logic of time travel, whilst certainly theoretically appealing, creates levels of silliness that no ordinary film could hope to cope with. I needn't bother revisiting the specific instances but suffice to say that the movie was forced to throw its own time travel logic out of the window almost before it had been elaborated by Banner in the early discussions, and continued to throw it out the window to the bitter end(game).There is one possible answer to this, which the more generous devotees might propose. Perhaps Banner is wrong about the past not affecting the future, but either doesn't know it or doesn't want to tell the others because the implications are too crazy to think about. Sadly this makes no sense on many levels, for instance because Tony Stark would clearly have invented time travel a lot earlier had he been aware of time traveling versions of himself and others before the whole Infinity War happened. This, the version of Stark visited and robbed by his future self certainly was, unless that technologically advanced SHIELD building had no CCTV.In conclusion, love the time travel concept proposed by this film. It deserves a thorough treatment in a film willing to explore its weird implications. But sadly this movie does not follow it through, and never could have done, given all the mad fights, one-liners and dramatic moments they had to fit in.In hindsight, it looks like the Russos were desperate, they painted themselves into a corner, and they resorted in the end(game) to the last refuge of the script charlatan - an inconsistent time travel premise - to creep out of it. It was still a fun time. But a quality film or satisfying conclusion to the story arc, not so much.

Okay, again I don't know how to define Miss Marvel, she sometimes seems powerful, but other times seems weak and most of the time completely useless. She claims not to have time for Earth when Thanos snapped, yet if she had been there she might have help or prevented it from happening in the first place.
Yet I don't know if she has the power, as it's all over the place. Okay, she somehow flies and shots energy beams by getting the power from the Space Stone ? Makes no senses.
But at last she's got powers, strong enough to fly through leaser beams and a spaceship, yet not strong enough to get past common foot soldiers ?
Okay a fluke I guess.
Later she tries to take the gauntlet from Thanos, something even Cap. American almost did alone, yet she can't, but she can take a headbutt from him no problem, it is almost like he is all CGI right there. Sigh
And she has the IG for a long time, yet she never takes it on to end the treat, no it has to be a normale human that does that, even though it seems she would handle that power just as good as the Hulk,as she did adsorb powers from a stone with no problems. And she has plenty of time while the female "heroes" assembles around her to help her, becasue her powers are all over the place.Why did you take so much away from Thor and Hulk, we really needed the two most powerful heroes in this fight, yet they are reduced to jokes most of the time, and Thor just say that he is no leader in the end, yet that was what Thor 3 was all about.Then there is the death of Black Widow, the one we all hoped would finally get a movie, guess this is Disney's way of telling us no on that.
The death of Ironman felt like the death of the Marvel Universe, the journey that came to a close and was telegraphed from a mile away.
And lastly you made Cap. America grow old, at least with his love, but it would have been better to show his slow aging instead, so he could still be a supporter to the cause.I feel like this is the last movie of Avengers we will ever get, as they are almost all dead, left or retired, and the supporting actors don't seem like they will go on either. We will get Spiderman and GoTG I hope, but it really will not feel tied in any longer.Also there is a huge plot hole in the movie, as there is now double the amount of all people again, yet for the last 5 years they have only needed to grow food for the ones that din't die, so there will be world hunger for years on all planets. Not to mention all those that died because the pilot, driver, nuclear engineer and so on was snapped away will still be dead.
So there will be lots of wars and unrest in all the world, not to mention the people that came back is 5 years younger in mind and body, but would be 5 years older according to the justice system and so on, and would have been declared dead so they wouldn't have any assets either.

Endgame consistently felt off from the start to the end. The tone is just strange, the pacing is messy and the plotholes are ridiculous and badly effect the enjoyment of the film. That said there are some fun scenes.This felt more like a tying up of loose ends rather than a real self-contained film. While I liked Infinity War they really backed themselves into a corner when they got time travel involved. So many plot holes and convoluted plot lines concerning time travel.... How is Captain America able to come back at the end if he has gone to a different time line? This is a direct contradiction of something they said previously in the film - that going back into time does not change the future. But, lo and behold, Captain America is suddenly in this very timeline, but somehow without affecting it? This makes no sense.How does Captain Marvel know where Tony Stark is??! In the vast endless expanse of space she somehow randomly comes across him!!? This is never explained.Stark figuring out time travel in about 2 minutes is just laughable.How can Thanos be so powerful without the infinity gauntlet so that he can easily defeat Thor, Iron man and Captain America all at once?!? This was the most fun fight scene by far but it is partly ruined by its illogical premises. Reminds me of Star Trek Discovery where we are supposed to be dazzled by the spectacle and not take plot continuity seriously anymore.As other people have pointed out they ruined the character development they had set up with Thanos' character. This wonderfully rich character is killed in the first 5 mins of the film. Only to be replaced by his more one dimensional past self later. It might as well have been any generic bad guy. There is no satisfying link to the Thanos of the first film.Fat comedy Thor really disrespects his character and just looks and feels so silly. They could have made him depressed and overweight sure, but why make it so pronounced that it becomes hard to take seriously. He has become a (bad) parody of himself. I like the comedy element of these films but please take it back a notch.The interactions between Stark and Rodgers seemed stale and repetitive. It was hard to care anymore. I actually liked the Hulk/Banner hybrid - this was one of the more inventive/original parts of the film. It would have been good to see him actually fight! I liked the interactions between Hawkeye and Black Widow. Their relationship has always been interesting/layered and well acted.The final battle scene felt like a rehash of the one in Wakanda. So, again, hard to get excited about something we have seen before. But of course, it has its fun moments. I loved seeing Scarlet Witch take on Thanos one on one and get the better of him until he calls on the big guns.It seems like the story line of IW bit off more than it could chew. It becomes so overblown and fantastical that it is hard to take seriously anymore. A bit of an anti-climax. But of course its still a must-see because its the culmination of a decade of Marvel films. I still enjoyed this film to an extent, its just a bit disappointing. I could have easily sat through another hour of this if it helped sort out the pacing problems and made more sense of things.

The movie had an epic tale and fights and humor like you would expect in a Marvel movie....butThis is a spoilerWhen the people are brought back, they bring them back 5 YEARS after they left and I presume they ended up in the exact same spot.
If 3.5 BILLION people were to suddenly materialize there would not be enough food, shelter or ability to deal with them. The entire world economy and welfare would self-destruct.After 5 years many people would have moved on...married other people, moved away changed jobs whereas the people 'coming back' would have nothing since they would have probably been declared dead.What about someone coming back into their old bedroom only arrive while another couple (who bought the house from the estate of the person who vanished) were having sex.What about people who vanished from cars on the highway. Did they return only to be run down and killed?That flaw ruins a good story for me. I expect a bit of stupidity in any movie to fit a script to a story, but this one was too glaring to deal with.

No better words can describe this bizarre and uncomfortable anomaly. It carries a sanctimony dwarfing even Saving Private Ryan, as cinema history now replaces actual history. As the camera passed the ensemble, I saw Michael Douglas and my eyes immediately looked for Charlie Sheen. Michelle Pfeiffer in black drab, I looked for Barnabas Collins. The great popcorn funeral, then why stop short at Marvel? In fact the death of America is all across this. (The subliminal programming of Joe Biden as Captain America was screamingly obvious.) Remember, none of this is preposterous as the movie itself. The time heist is closest to examining its theater in the way of Dickens, which provides a decade of cinema to act against so continues this new tradition of cinema as memory functioning via its own footage as our own psychology on screen. It's always regret, what if, accepting failure, parental. "When you time travel, time fights back." It's saying the universe is self-aware, unfolding, and we play into it. See how most in the past are willing to accept the truth--except--when they face themselves, then it's antagonism and sarcasm in every case. As in ego in the way of the collectivist utopia. Most interesting is Thanos's relationship with future Thanos, they never meet, but the villain aiding himself in outcomes as the output adjusts the input, creates a cinema study in machine learning as omnipotence. "A world where no one knows the horrors that led to their existence." This is already the case. Remember he won 11,999,999 times, making this film in god's eye where the monkeys bash the keyboard to a perfect series of events in self-sacrifice and the unity of the collectivist hive: the women army, the buddhist army, the african army, twenty films join in one to destroy the fascist eugenicist. But with twelve million realities and just one being our film, then isn't half dying overwhelmingly the lesser of evils compared to millions of realities everyone died due to their meddling? Their good intention becomes an abominable evil compared to Thanos's great heroism in saving half the universe. Lastly, the 'all in one' showdown is like Ready Player One except the Oasis is the cinema screen itself. Cinema is realizing a mind of its own and turning the game against us. (Should Marvel have a seat in the UN next?) Theater was once a vessel for humanity to ritualize its experience in boldness and vividness, now instead humanity is the vessel of cinema to awaken itself to our form. The hyper-reactivity doesn't pantomime our dramas rather it's the agenda of the hyper A.I. to replace us with this sort of proto-idealism. All the while we merrily train the borg like captcha through our dollars giving it the exact schematics to dictate us. The snap of the thumb kills the audience instead.

That movie was so emotional, yet full of action. Funny, yet deep with meaning. As an avid MCU Films fan, the Avengers: Endgame was by far THE BEST MCU FILM. For 10 years MCU has always delivered blockbuster movies and Endgame felt like their BIG BANG or LAST HURRAH; a trophy for all the 20 MCU films we have seen and loved.Sitting through a 3-hour film never felt this quick but it was not short of satisfaction. It gave me all the feels, from laughs, to tears, to being in awe, to surprises.However, I wouldn't recommend watching this without watching all the MCU Films before this.Avengers: Endgame is WORTH THE HYPE. This is the finale that will stay with us.

Some great moments but so many disappointing ones in the midst of it all:1. Thor from the Thor movies and the avengers ones previously to this Thor was easily the most annoying aspect.2. HULK... any need for him when he doesn't smash or add to action scenes?? He's a wasted character for several movies now so not quite as disappointing as Thor but you might as well just have Bruce Banner character only without any "green"-ness as far as I'm concerned.3. Euphoria of some of the scenes dwindling away with the following scene but unnecessarily dragged out was criminal. Infinity war in comparison I walked out of the cinema completely blown away and giddy but it just wasn't like that in endgame.4. Plot holes (unless I misunderstood the whole time travelling issue), how was the future nebula able to kill the past nebula with no repercussions? I'm coming at this as someone who read the comics and who also invested in this franchise since 2008 as a 15 year old kid, when I was the only one in my entire high school or inner circle who could comprehend what was about to unfold and told everyone about who The Avengers were and what they're all about.To be frank, time traveling is a lazy way to rewrite or undo everything that came before. But, there are films that do it well and I was going in with that optimism that they might try something clever. Ultimately it is the same time traveling mumbo-jumbo. It does try to cover the tried trope with moments of nostalgia, and to it's credit it even made me feel that way.But with that being said, that wasn't the biggest issue, it was some of the character decisions that the Russos, Feige and writers Markus & McFeely chose. I cannot review this without spoilers, so here it goes.I really disliked Thor's arc. I didn't appreciate the joke they made him into. It just didn't work for me. I've elaborated many times, more often than not the MCU's child-like and formulaic humor can really get on my nerves. I was expecting a tone just a little more dower, similar to Infinity War. I like it when things are taken a little more seriously which is why I put Infinity War, Civil War, The Winter Soldier, and the first Iron Man on such high pedestal. Seeing him out of shape and acting like a frat-boy was unpleasant. Odin's lesson of being there for his people has been lost with Thor's ending, it's as if all the growth in Ragnarok was gone in this film.As for Captain America, well, I did find it kinda fitting, but I would have preferred to have seen Rogers make the ultimate sacrifice himself alongside Tony Stark. The universe revolves around both of them and I personally would have found it more poetic if the two heartbeats of the MCU go out in heroic fashion. Ultron once called him out on "pretending to live without war." As much as I found Ultron to be a tad underwhelming, I found that quote from him to have poignancy and also one of the reasons why Captain America is so interesting. Tony Stark, can't help himself but to always fix things, with Steve Rogers, he cannot turn away from any situation that goes south. Even if time traveling in this film apparently splits off to another parallel timeline, I still don't find it in Steve Rogers who gave up his own love, his own time to the greater good, to only check out and retire like the way he did.I had no problem with Tony's death, as a matter of fact I love the fact that Endgame wasn't afraid to kill Black Widow and Iron Man. The MCU started with Downey's Iron Man, so I found it reasonable that it should end with him. Nat's death only develops Hawkeye, who has way more to do in this film than he ever did in the previous installments. It was time for the MCU to not have any "fake-outs" and really show that heroes can die. I remember what Whedon said during his tenure with Marvel. It's war, and in war people die, and when the war is won, there is always a cost in a victory.Thanos this time around got the short end of the stick. Brolin again delivers on his performance, and I understand, this movie is more about the Avengers than it is about Thanos, but I just did not like the fact that they killed him in the first twenty minutes and we got a pre-Infinity War Thanos.But, the Big Three, Downey Jr, Evans and Hemsworth deliver. The rest of the cast is good. Jeremy Renner is at his best here like I previously mentioned. Johansson is also very good, and it was nice to see her and Renner's characters bounce off each other like they used to, making her death only more tragic. Karen Gillan who salvaged a small portion of the redundant Guardians 2, also brings her A-game and Nebula's arc here is handled very well. It was also very cool to see Professor Hulk and Ruffalo does a great job being at peace with himself. The rest of the cast, Larson, Cheadle, Rudd, and Cooper are great.Now, we all knew the dusted would return, and that scene really gave me goosebumps momentarily. The action in this film is not on the level of Infinity War. It's solid action, and some very cool moments, but it pales in comparison to the Titan fight, the Wakanda battle, and the opening NY fight in Infinity War. Thanos does however go against the Big Three and that was a treat, especially his fight against Cap, but the rest of the action lacked the extra flare that made the fight sequences in Infinity War so awesome. At the very least, the characters are used well. VFX is also top notch.Ultimately, I enjoyed good amount of moments within the film, and technically speaking it's very well made, but I walked out of this unfulfilled and unsatisfied. I'm not comfortable with the direction they took, especially on the characters I mentioned and I know putting people up to my standards is ridiculous, but I can have high expectations for this because again, I've invested in the MCU for 10+ years. I'll need time to let it sink in and maybe if I watch it again I'll think differently, but its as if the Russos and Markus & McFeely exhausted all options and ran out of gas after delivering film after film.7/10

Totally worth a watch and it caps the series off well but it's pacing is a bit erratic for my tastes.It'll be interesting to see what comes in the new phases. I won't say more because this movie deserves to have none of the secrets spoiled.Go see it guys.
Ehh it was predictable and the last one was better

Well...most of them.The film opens on Jeremy Renner's Hawkeye with his happy family...until he no longer has one on account of them being dusted, which causes him to become vengeful Mohawkeye. Next up it's my least favourite Avenger, Tony Snark, teaching games to Nebula (my favourite Guardian of the Galaxy and the only one of those a-holes I actually LIKE. Mantis, who I also like and who *isn't* an a-hole, sadly only gets one line in the movie, but at least it's a funny one). The term drawn-out could be used to describe this whole opening with Tony. 'Self-indulgent' would be another. Just because you have a 3-hour+ runtime, Russos, doesn't mean you should waste it lingering on Tony sleeping, etc. I did appreciate, though, that Nebula shows she's grown (as evidenced by the fact she's refrained from beating the snot out of Tony the entire time they've been stuck in space together). I was happy to see her featured so much.Thankfully things finally get moving once Captain Marvel saves their butts and interacts with the team in a scene most have probably watched already. As she points out to rude Rhodey (whose main role seems to be Joke/Movie Reference Man), she's been on other planets after 'The Snap' that *didn't* have The Avengers to help them out. The fact that THOR says he likes her should be enough (though obviously won't be for certain people). He also learns from the mistake he made at the end of Infinity War regarding what bodypart to aim for on Thanos (who apparently wiped out half the universe's populace so he could become a farmer and unfortunately destroyed the Infinity Stones). Too bad Nebula's robbed of the chance to end Thanos in this movie (twice!), as she probably deserved to the most. Tony the Drama Queen proves he hasn't grown at all, laying the blame for everything at Cap's feet.A skip to five years later reveals time hasn't been kind to Thor. I'm saddened to see him reduced to this joke, when the first Thor movie is one of my favourites. They've veered too far into 'comedy' for my taste, as here he's played mostly for laughs on account of letting himself go (for those wanting shirtless Thor, you'll get him...though you'll wish you *hadn't*). Bless Paul Rudd's Scott Lang, as he brings a breath of fresh air to proceedings. His reunion with his (now grown) daughter is one of the few genuinely effective emotional moments in the film. Unfortunately, he's not given the respect he deserves, considering he's the one to come up with the idea of time travel (the subject of which is given the ultimate nerd discussion in this film). They go to Tony, who selfishly refuses to help the others get back everyone they lost since he already HAS everyone HE wants (well...except for Spider-Kid, who is the reason he eventually changes his mind).Cut to after a 'comedic' sequence involving working out the kinks of time-travelling, the gang splits up to retrieve all the stones from the past. This is where the film kicks into gear, as we revisit past MCU films and encounter previous versions of characters. Highlights include: Cap seeing Peggy Carter again, Cap vs Past Cap, Thor spending some precious time with his soon-to-be-deceased mother (plus, a Jane cameo! There's actually lots of cameos in the film, but only a few I cared about) and twice the amount of Nebula. There's one rage-inducing consequence of visiting the past involving Mohawkeye, Natasha and the Soul Stone. If you remember what happened with Gamora, you'll know what that means. Although the character who ends up being the sacrifice gets some good character/emotional beats in this film, it still doesn't make up for the fact they're unceremoniously given the 'permadeath' treatment, thus robbing us of one of the MCU's best characters and the awesome dynamics between them and other characters. Given all the others that could've been offed, WHY'd it have to be...well...you'll see.I'll give the film credit for seamlessly blending the 'present' characters with the past, and once things reach the climax, they definitely ensure this is the most 'epic' battle we've seen yet which involves pretty much every character (except those who're unfortunate enough to *stay* dead, of course), some of which will be getting future films or TV shows to appear in. I guess that's meant to 'make up for' them not getting much screentime here (like my fave, Wanda. At least she gets some revenge on Thanos and shares an emotional moment with Mohawkeye near the end. I'm looking forward to her show and hopefully future movie appearances too). Captain America gets at least two cheer-worthy moments, while Captain Marvel and her new haircut get to kick some major arse (don't fret, haters...she isn't given the final victory over Thanos. No, we all know who gets THAT privilege).I guess I was supposed to feel sad near the end, but honestly I just felt relief, as it's about time a certain someone faced some actual real consequences. Hopefully other characters will get to thrive/have substantial screentime now that somebody isn't hogging it all. Another good thing about the end is the camera shot which slowly moves through/covers everyone (all these characters we've come to know, plus a few we haven't yet) at the funeral. The BEST part, however, is the final scene. I've waited ever since the first Cap movie (my other fave MCU film) to get to the scene that ends this movie, and I think it's worth it. I'm so very happy with it and who it involves.While there're no mid-credits/post-credits scenes, it's worth sticking around to see the original six Avengers actors literally signing off. It'll probably take a couple of viewings to fully digest this film, as it throws in everything AND the kitchen sink. It's a fitting conclusion to Phase 3 (ignoring Spider-Kid 2). Now, bring on Phase 4!

Thank God I *didn't* see this on Thursday night like I originally wanted to. Man, did I feel every...single...one of those 181 minutes.Don't get me wrong, I liked the movie. Some scenes were definitely funny, some touched me tremendously and I had a huge warmth in my heart for nostalgia for the other MCU chapters. But, boy...one full hour could've been cut and the tightened film would've been so much better.My father, who joined me during this film, had not seen Avengers 3a (ah-hem, "Infinity War.") So, before this 3b part (aka: "Endgame,") I took roughly 10 seconds to explain that first part to this conclusion movie. I summed up 2½ hours of footage...in 10 seconds. He didn't think it sounded like a good movie, to which I corrected him. Part 3a was a great movie and you never felt those 2½ hours because it was chock-full of action, almost non-stop. Just because it had a basic premise, it still had depth and so much going on, you should be on the edge of your seat the entire film.And the opposite is true here. This is what I recall feeling when I watched Kill Bill Vol 2. I was so excited because Kill Bill Vol 1 was so action-packed and fun, I was looking forward to the same in the concluding volume. Nope. The breaks were put on from like 90mph to 15.Again, don't get me wrong. I really did enjoy both Kill Bill Vol. 2 and this Avengers 3b movie. It's just not what I expected in the least. It's definitely well made, thought out and has all the elements you desire. It just takes such a long time to get the goods. And by goods, I'd say, aside from all the one-off great scenes of comedy/reminiscence, the climax had me almost out of my seat, clapping and cheering.The neat part of this experience was the aftermath. Rarely do we get to see the actual destruction after an evil villain actually succeeds like Thanos did in Part 3a. 3b is that movie. This is the What-If-Comes-Sadly-True. And I enjoyed that idea a bit until the movie finally kicks in - about an hour or so in.Not gonna ruin any specifics, but suffice to say, the movie's, naturally, about the Avengers attempting to figure out how to win after the last movie's defeat. Kinda like Return of the Jed-I to The Empire Strikes Back. (Though...Star Wars Episode VI does a much better job of the same story.)Is this a recommendation? Of course. Go and slam your money down and get a ticket. There is absolutely zero reason to NOT see this if you've seen Part 3a or, hell, any of the other MCU. But, maybe just once. Okay, twice, with the second time at home to catch anything you might have missed. And keep in mind, overall it's best to have seen ALL 21 prior movies to really appreciate/understand this one.***Final thoughts: Whew! I think I did it. I think I wrote a completely spoiler-free review. These kinds of movies takes me off social media the whole week leading up to my weekend viewing as I am worried about spoilers. I guess, you're welcome.

The most anticipated film of the year: Reviewing "Avengers: Endgame" (NO SPOILERS)Saying this film gives fan service does not even begin to scratch the surface, as it is littered from beginning to end with quips. humor, forced appearances and minor characters. While being a send off to the old and an introduction to the new, this film was literally the end of the MCU as we know it, making me personally fear for the future of the franchise. It's not a bad film by any means, but it also fails to live up to the hype and emotion promised, although my screening was filled with thunderous applause, laughter, and literal sobbing at the end. Endgame is sort of a mess, and the story goes everywhere until finally reaching the climax. The film is split into three acts, all of which go entirely different directions, the first act is somber, yet humorous, for no reason at all. The second act is slightly confusing, but brilliant, bringing us back to different moments remembered throughout the MCU, and the third act is an all-out battle, not filmed particularly well. As far as films that wrap up a series go, with the 3-hour plus run-time, most of "Endgame" falls into the extremely average category, as more character growth should have been realized and the full potential of the original six Avengers, minus a couple, was never fully realized. Robert Downey Jr., Chris Evans, and Jeremy Renner stand out in their respective roles, where Scarlett Johanson, Mark Ruffalo, and Chris Hemsworth feel greatly under utilized. The more modern Avengers cast is fresh, for the most part, but we begin to see where the MCU has over-saturated the franchise itself, as some characters that are even in briefly are far too invincible for a Universe based in modern times. The conclusion of the film will bring tears to some, but it's the closing the original MCU deserves after 11 long years. See it in the theater. "Infinity War" was the superior film. 7.5/10
