After 21 films worth of waiting, Marvel has finally reached the conclusion to the Infinity Saga in Avengers: Endgame. The collective movies had mad billions of dollars, and captured the hearts of comic book fans around the world. The prior entry, Avengers: Infinity War added a certain sense of gravitas and catharsis to the Marvel Universe. The prior film left fans not only devastated, but with more questions than answers with it's cliffhanger, serial ending. So how does the conclusion fare? Are the Fallen avenged? Is Endgame worth the hype?One of my greatest praises of Shazam! was the amount of personal consequence it had. One of my biggest criticisms of most superhero movies is that the consequence is constantly about saving the world. This then makes saving the world a redundant outcome that we know the superheroes will eventually solve. With constant resurrections and story revisions, the Marvel Universe greatly lacked this. Yet even though the world saving was still the primary conflict of Endgame, the story contained personal consequence for each individual character that made the film far more endearing to the viewer. This filled the film with incredibly written, visceral moments of joy, pain, and everything in between.The amount of story-boarding that went into the film is insane. The run time is long, but a necessary evil to the human bladder to tie up so many loose ends within an incredibly convoluted plot. The Marvel Cinematic Universe has so many characters, and Endgame gives resolution to their individual strife, while raising questions that can be pursued in future films. It gives each character their own space in the spotlight while concurrently sharing it equally. It is absolute brilliant direction by the Russo brothers.I cannot justifiably call Endgame the singular greatest superhero film of all time. Nolan's Dark Knight trilogy is still brilliant, and did not need 21 films of buildup. Yet it absolutely rivals the trilogy with the first Marvel film that takes a chance with the ultimate pathos. The film rewards the fans who have seen all of the films, even the poorer entries, while inviting new fans with instant accessibility. I never checked my watch, I never felt the need to get up from my seat, which is something that has never occurred for me within a three hour movie. Not every direction choice worked as intended, not every story point was logistically flawless, but it still works. I laughed, I cried, and sometimes even did bof. Not both, but BOF. I can't give Avengers:Endgame any grade worse than perfect.(Grade: 10/10)

After watching this, I must say that the film is a bit hyped up and not excellent as a lot of reviewers have given it, but is overall a good solid film.The first three quarters of the film was quite slow paced to be honest. I feel as though they should have distributed the action and tension scenes throughout the film rather than kept most of it for the final quarter. The last action scene seemed a bit rushed also but had some nice moments. There are plenty of comedic and fan service scenes throughout, but just lacked the tension, action and the banter scenes (especially the ones between Ironman and Dr Strange) that I had really enjoyed in the previous Infinity War film.Some vague spoilers below:There are occasional sad scenes, especially at the end, if you're a Marvel film fan or watched many of the previous ones, and it seems that they have finished off the Avengers franchise, or at least have killed off some of the main characters, which is sad. Saying that, they have opened up the doors to expand the Marvel universe.I found the sub- plot line, in which they have to retrieve the soul stone, a little silly to be honest. They have copied it from the previous one and how did the characters not know that a sacrifice is required?? Although it was nice to see some of the time travel scenes, I think the story would have worked much better if the time travel element was left out. That is my opinion though.Hope you enjoy the film though. 8/10.

You had to do it This way?? I mean there wasn't any other options? I'm a crazy marvel fan, I die for any superhero movies, madly in love with avengers, but this ending ( which is literally the ending) p****d me off!
Ok first, why time travelling? It's soo lame and an old idea.
I'm so pissed off that I can't even for a second say a good thing about this movie, because of all the disappointments.
You really had to make Thor fat? Yeah we laughed a bit at first but that's it. They literally destroyed his god-ness,badassness, the greatest image. Dude, he was a damn god that everyone in theatre cheered for when landed on Earth in infinity war! And they changed him with a homeless guy. Very godly! And captain picks up his hammer (yeah he is also worthy (long live America), so they should have killed this pathetic person. Free him of his misery).The idea of hulk being able to take control of the other guy is ok (even though cliche), but if they can co-exists then bring him when needed!!!!!! Don't be like a stupid happy, calm person who just did yoga. What's the point??!You had to kill iron man? Of course it's a great ending and everyone will cry, every fan will say ' I love you 3000', but was it necessary? He literally was the only avengers ( other than hawk-eye, but seriously compare to others, no one cares for him)who had something to care, to lose, to love. He was happy. It's like they really wanted to make people emotional and cry, so let's kill the beloved arrogant, funny one. I mean Thor has nothing to lose, Natasha, Hulk, even Captain America. But no, kill iron man.Some scenes were meant to be epic, have meanings but ended up being too forced and unreal. Like the "girls-power, femenism" scene. Yeah all the women are there, it was too forced.
And the end of Captain America, he just decided to stay, and it was accepted! We can just forget the time travelling problems with that! But why? Because they wanted to make a happy ending for him. And he gave his shield to a black guy? Just again to satisfy some other viewers. It is so forced.I really don't care if no one agrees, obviously many says it's 10/10. And it is impossible to satisfy everyone.
actually I'm jealous of those who were satisfied. I wish I was too.
I mean what is there to say other than wow this movie is just incredible. WOW
Absolutely loved it, every character gets a good chunk of screen time and they all use it to full effect, its laugh out loud funny at times, really touching at times.

The first time ever I physically facepalmed in cinema (those who saw it will know exactly which scene I mean...)Very similar to Infinity War - two thirds of the movie feels great, but the rest consists of "epic" action scenes and predictable "close calls" dumb and unrealistic to the point of me taking offense at the creators either considering me too stupid to notice, or worse, not even caring; followed by "emotional" scenes that are just too damn long, forced and badly acted to work.One unfortunate difference from Infinity War is that it still had a fantastic Thanos and a half-believable plot.I know physics don't apply in comic book movies, but I know a battle scene that I can enjoy doesn't have more than 5 participants and doesn't last 45 minutes!
Right, yay for teamwork, good guys have each others back and beat a formidable solo villain, it's corny but I get it. But there's a point when it's too much, and that point is about half way of where these movies take it.
A fight scene is epic when it builds up, not when 25 "heroes" - including every insignificant sidekick - take turns fighting random cannon fodder and/or a stronger villain who flicks them aside instead of finishing them off.
*SPOILERS BELOW*
Infinity War's ending moved me at least a bit, despite Ironman's "acting" and me being sadly certain of them reversing it anyway(oh boy did I hope I was wrong...). In Endgame, the supposedly moving events are permanent and I felt nothing. The "epic" battle was such a mockery that I just stopped caring. It's not that almighty universe-moving stones are now finger-snapping toys that every human can safely hold - as long he looks good and carries a bow. Not even that young Thanos is suddenly unstoppable even without the stones, even against Marvel.
It's the whole dumb scene good army vs bad army, it's the asgard chick I didn't care about even in Thor 3, arriving on a damn pegassus, it's Pepper in armor. And no matter how impotent Captain America feels throwing a shield around, the hammer? For the love of Stan, WHY?It could've been a good movie, just reduce it by 1 hour by cutting final battle to 15 min and emo scene to 5, oh well, maybe I'm the weirdo...
Great movie But not better then infinity war. Ending was the best part of it

Avengers: Endgame is not a perfect movie, but it feels like one. Every character get an end to their arcs, and the film itself is a great conclusion to 11 years of movies, all of which have led up to this. I wont spoil the actual plot for those who haven't seen it (the trailers have been incredible at not revealing anaything), but I will say that it is full of surprises, shocks, laughs and tears. The fact that the film manages to be THIS good more than makes up for its few flaws. The final battle is probably the most fan-pleasing, epic and emotionaly packed action sequence in any superhero movie; it was the culmiation if 11 years of characters we've come to love and care about. This is what superhero movies are all about.

An epic end to the this Infinity Saga..It couldn't have been any better..To all those fans around the globe who have been waiting for this moment. I have to say this is worth Ur wait, this is the moment, this is the Endgame

After seeing ENDGAME for the second time, I'm ready to write my review, which will be difficult to do without spoilers. I find it interesting that those who gave INFINITY WAR a 10 were disappointed in this movie and I think I know why (for I am one of them) - INFINITY WAR took so many characters, such different tones in the worlds of the different heroes, with such a big story arc, yet managed to tell real stories interweaving the larger story, not just 3 minute cameos. ENDGAME, although having real moments of pathos, missed that balance. Despite moments of humour (many at cost of Thor's character, which I didn't appreciate), this movie basically had one tone and I was disappointed how some of our heroes were marginalized (and given bad haircuts). I know it was the end of an era, a passing of the torch. As a friend put it, "Character development was never the focus of this movie, that was what all the previous movies were for...it was a perfect wrap up and set up for the next arc." I agree this was all about the ensemble but there were edits (or complete changes) to our heroes' journeys for which I didn't care (too many stories were left off screen) with one exception (Nebula has a character arc). So, that's why I didn't enjoy this as much as INFINITY WAR yet it was still a great movie with great performances by all the cast, poignant moments of loss, great montages in the battle scenes and a real challenge demanding great cost. Kudos to the Russos and Kevin Feige for their hands at the tiller for this era. I give this film an 8 (great) out of 10. {Superheroes Action Adventure}

Infinity war was way better, in my opinion. There was a lot of plot holes in the movie to begin with. They had many cringe bathos moments and they crammed in too much emotional elements just to make the movie a n uplifting finale.

When I first saw the 3 hour run time I was excited that we'd get an even bigger and greater story than Infinity War. I was wrong and wouldn't be surprised if this run time was only created to create more hype. Instead, we got plenty of pointless and boring scenes that add nothing to the characters or the universe. The first two hours are sleep inducing because there's a boring plot that I can't see anyone caring about. The last hour or so is the only part of the film that I'd want to see again, it's very much fan service but it was very fun to watch.Some other problems I had: The film doesn't even listen to its own rules of time travel when Captain America goes back with Peggy(I could be wrong about this though), Nebula was the only character that I felt any emotion for, instead of making an interesting and complex new story line after Thanos' death they just decided to have Thanos come back except this time he's the generic bad guy that wants to destroy the entire universe and create a new one(literally Cyrus from the "Pokemon" franchise), I believe the Hulk dabs, Thor yells at some kid on Fortnite(why was this even in the movie other than to just promote the game because they're having some stupid Endgame crossover event) and the "first canonically gay character" in the film was given disappointing and was shoved into the movie for a 2 minute scene that was pointless. I feel like the gay character was added to create more attention and to say "wow, a gay character. we're so progressive, gay people come buy a ticket to see!"Overall, the movie was enjoyable. The first two hours may have been a drag but the final hour is very well deserved and is the best way the MCU could've ended. I've said this earlier that it's fan service but I don't see anything wrong with that because it's one hell of a fight. Seeing the Avengers group up made me jump in my seat and seeing the female Avengers charge together was also one of my favorite parts of the movie.
Lazy plotline used(timetravel) a good climax but the rest was pretty boring. Only people who love the mcu would think this is an above average movie.

One thing about time travel that no one seems to get.
The first Rule of time travel is:
You can not change anything in the past that lead to creating time travel in the first place.
Assuming that the Avengers didn't change any thing and the reason for creating the machine remaind the same
The big dramatic fight between the armies would not exist for 1 reason
if the Thanos and his team who came from the past died in the future after the 5 year mark the events that lead to creating the time machine disappear which means that they will not make the time machine and the whole branch will not happen
One more thing, where did the evil Army come from?
They were destroyed and scattered in the previous movie
Other than that every thing is perfect

This movie is so close to be perfect!! sooo close!!! you will find some mistakes... some bigger than others... but in general, this movie is smart, visually amazing, will make's you laugh and cry...So... SPOILERS?!The movie start showing you what happens to some of the characters, some people find this part "slow"... but for me was more than ok... Then... the preparation for the time travel and infinity stones heist start.This is the "smart" part... they found a way to use the stones in a way that don't affect the other movies, or at least that's what they try, for me this is the part they "F"up things... there are some timeline nightmares after this movie!! things that affect characters in this movie, and even in the entire MCU.But apart from that, this movie deliver!! and deliver damn hard!!! the epicnes of the battle is "a la" Lord of the Rings" but "F"ing bigger!!! almost every character is here!! is like seeing "Ready Player One"... everyone is on-screen and you don't want to blink your eyes, because you can loose something!More than one character will die... and those scenes are damn sad... if you are all-in in the MCU, you will cry!!!I give it a 9 just because the time travel mistakes, but more because Captain Marvel... omg... she's so powerful!! that is painful... marvel is going on a path that I don't want to go... I mean... I love Scarlet With, The Wasp is damn badass! even if she's just a human on a suit... but my favorite is Black Widow! just a regular human... no powers, no amazing gadgets... but Captain Marvel? she don't belong to the same universe... there is no logic's on why she's so powerful! and after investing more than 10 years on those characters, Captain Marvel feels more like Captain Mary Sue. THANKFULLY she don't do that much... but you can see how Mary Sue she is anyway.AMAZING MOVIE!!! the (almost) perfect way to close this incredible story... A MUST SEE!!!!!!!

I will keep this first part of the review short, but add some footnotes (indexed with <#> symbols) to a "spoiler section" below the trailer videofurther down. Proceed at your peril if you haven't yet seen it!The MCU has delivered an impressively well-connected movie series. In the case of Thanos, this is a story-arc that started in the mid-credit "monkey" at the end of 2012's "The Avengers" and, at the conclusion of "Avengers: Infinity War", saw half the universe's population drift away - Voldemort-style - into grey ash. This, of course, also wiped out half of our heroes. This included Spider-Man (Tom Holland); Dr Strange (Benedict Cumberbatch); Black Panther (Chadwick Boseman); Nick Fury (Samuel L. Jackson); half of the remaining Guardians; The Wasp (Evangeline Lilly) and Dr Pym (Michael Douglas). Oblivious to all of this is Ant Man (Paul Rudd), still stranded in the 'quantum realm' following the demise of his colleagues, and with no one to flick the 'return' switch.After some early action, Endgame's story revolves around a desperate attempt by the remaining Avengers, led by Black Widow (Scarlett Johansson) and a 'retired' Tony Stark (Robert Downey Jnr) to undo the undoable. Can they succeed against all the odds? (With a new Spider-Man film due out in the summer, I'll give you a guess!). Of more relevance perhaps is whether the team can stay unscathed from their encounter with the scheming and massively powerful Thanos (Josh Brolin)?The film will not be to every fan's taste. After the virtually non-stop rip-roaring action of "Infinity War", "Endgame" takes a far more contemplative approach to its first hour.The film starts with a devastating prologue, and a great lesson in statistics: that you need a decent sized population to guarantee getting a 50:50 split! There is also a very surprising twist in the first 15 minutes or so that I didn't see coming AT ALL.But then things settle down into a far more sombre section of the film: short on action; long on character development. The world is grieving for its loss, unable to move on past the non-stop counselling sessions that everyone is getting. This first hour was, for me, by far, my favourite part of the film. Seeing how the characters we know and love have been impacted - some for better rather than for worse - was terrific. Mark Ruffalo's Hulk (with a rather glib plot-point) takes on an hilarious new aspect; and Chris Hemsworth adds hugely comedic value as Thor, setting up in Scotland a "New Asgard" settlement in uncharacteristically laid-back fashion.As an ensemble cast, everyone plays their parts extremely well. But it is just the breadth of the cast that astounds in this film: just about everyone who is anyone in the Marvel Universe - at least, those who are still alive (alive!) and not dead (dead!) - pop up for an appearance! This is great fun with, in one particular case, the opportunity to try some more rejuvenation of an old timer as previously done with Samuel L. Jackson in "Captain Marvel".Inevitably, some of these appearances are overly brief, and characters that I wanted to see developed more in this film (particularly Brie Larson's Captain Marvel) get very little screen time. Drax (Dave Bautista) and Mantis (Pom Klementieff) barely get a single line each. So it will depend on where your loyalties lie as to whether you are satisfied with the coverage or not. (I personally find Chris Evans' Captain America a bit of a po-faced bore, so I wasn't keen on the amount of screen time he had).Stan Lee again gets another cameo in the bag before his demise: will this actually be his last live one?Overall, I enjoyed this movie. It could obviously NEVER live up to the over-hyped expectations of the fan base. But as a cinematic spectacle, for me, it delivered on its billing as a blockbuster finale, but one filled with a degree of nuance I was not expecting. The problem with the way that the plot have been structured (no spoilers - <#>) is that it is easy to pick holes in the storyline. Indeed, some dramatic options (that to me seemed obvious ones to 'mine') were left 'unmined' <##>; others were left inexplicably hanging <###>.I suspect the reason for some of this is that the initial cut of this film probably ran to 5 hours rather than the - still bladder-testing - 3 hours as released. There were probably a bunch of scenes left on the cutting room floor that might allow things to make more sense in the extended BluRay release.It's at times slow, but for me never dull. It does suffer from one significant flaw though: the "Return of the King" disease. It doesn't know when to quit. There was a natural MCU arc to follow and a perfect time at which to end it: but the directors (the Russo Brothers, Anthony Russo and Joe Russo) kept adding additional scenes that detracted from the natural ending <####>.Above all, unlike I think all but one film in MCU history, there is NO "MONKEY" (end-credit scene) in the end credits: either mid-credit or end-credit! So, after the long title crawl (and some rather odd choices for end-title music by Alan Silvestri), if you are not to look bloody stupid as the lights come up, and face a storm of derision from your partner, then leave after the dramatic roll-call sequence of the film's stars!******SPOILER SECTION*****
Do not read beyond this point if you've not watched the film!<#>
The "plot-hole picking" business I referenced is of course the time-travelling element of the plot. First up, Stark's discovery of the mobius strip McGuffin is nicely done and his moral torment at disrupting the idyllic life he's built is relatable. But this timey-wimey stuff tends to play havoc with logic.....<##>
The missed opportunity I saw was the killing of Nebula (the younger) by Nebula (the elder) (both Karen Gillan). If it had been the other way round, I *might* have understood it. But surely this way round, Nebula the elder would have ceased to exist to go back in time in the first place? That's obviously a paradox! It would at least have been more satisfying if Nebula the elder had "ashed" away or something: literally a self-sacrifice for the greater good. Perhaps I've missed something and need to watch it again!<###>
My other question would be what happened to her sister Gamora? She was alive and kicking (hard) in one scene, but then not mentioned further: just a pining Star Lord (Chris Pratt) looking at her picture? Again, maybe I missed something!What was particularly joyous was seeing a plethora of great faces on the screen: Rene Russo (no immediate relation to the directors!) as Thor's mother; Natalie Portman, reprising her role of Jane Porter from the first Thor films (so brief, it was clearly constructed from cut footage or something); Michael Douglas, old and young, as Dr Pym and particularly Robert Redford. (So THIS, not "The Old Man and the Gun", is his "final film" then!!?)My previous reservations (from "Captain Marvel") about the superior fire-power of Captain Marvel also held true. Although she had "all the other planets" around the universe to cater for ("Fair point"), when she did turn up she ripped through Thanos's ship like paper (as she did in her own film). And yet she couldn't rip her way through Thanos? And a stone-less Thanos at that!This really made no sense to me. In "Infinity War" you could rationalise that the REASON the combined efforts of The Avengers to attack and remove the glove of Thanos failed was BECAUSE he was immensely powerful by having four of the five stones. In the battle scene in "Endgame" he had the better of Stark, Thor, Captain America AND Marvel but without any stones in his possession. Or have I missed something yet again here?<####>
My view of the finale was that it should have ended with the (rather CGI'd) funeral pan round the assembled characters (including a few randoms... I understand the young teen on his own was the kid who helped Stark in "Iron Man Three"). While the Captain America time travelling piece that followed was sweet and all, it's been done before (in Mel Gibson's "Forever Young" for example) and for me wasn't worth the minutes invested in it at the end of an already long film.So, where will we go from here then in the MCU universe? Stan Lee is dead; Stark is dead; Black Widow is dead (though - as Amy Andrews points out, in her excellent review of the movie - she's been criminally underused). There will no doubt be further MCU films: "SpiderMan: Far From Home" opens in the summer; surely we are due "Black Panther" and "Captain Marvel" follow-ups; ; and Ant-Man and the Wasp have barely scratched the surface together. But will we ever get to see another "Avengers-style" story arc that traverses and connects the characters again in a similar way? Only the timey-wimey stuff will tell.(For the full graphical review, please check out One Mann's Movies on the web or Facebook.)
Thank you for making us happy and satisfied. It's worth waiting for. 🍻

Spectacular, Emotional, Joyful, Unexpected, Filled with Actions.. Avengers Endgame is lifetime achievement.. It's the conclusion of 22 films.. It's like end of an era.. So please watch it in Imax or 3D and don't spoil the movie.. You'll enjoy it very much.. The ending is very satisfying..

After 11 years and 22 movies, Marvel Studios brought us the most ambitious movie, the greatest culmination, it is nostalgic, sentimental and completely unexpected. All the characters are so well-balanced, to each one is given plenty of screen time to development. If you're a marvel fan you'll feel like you're finally complete, you've never seen anything like this before, there are many references to all the 22 movies and there is a certain inevitability about the plot, there are plenty surprises. The movie present us an incredible balancing between nostalgia and novelty, you will scream, laugh and cry, it is the Marvel recipe elevated to the highest level. There's just so much in it, that I can't even write about it without spoiling everything. This is not the end for Marvel, but it certainly marks an ending for several of the characters we've watched and loved over the last decade, there will be more superhero franchises but it's hard to imagine any one being so culturally resonant.
It is the grande finale.
Without second thoughts I would say that it wad the most impressive work for Marvel.. makes you feel sad, happy, excited and thrilled to the max all in one movie

Let's tart with Thanos' plan. The guy is obviously not educated. He wants to solve the problem of the universe by wiping out half of the population. Which would solve nothing. So the film has a good pace that keeps me interested up-to the point when Thanos has won and retired to a planet far away (the first reality) ... then the avengers travel back in time and Thanos realises his plan will go well ... but here comes the first weakness in story ... if Thanos had all the stones ... knowing that the first snap didn't kill all the avengers, in all his wisdom and knowledge, he must have seen the possibility that there will be a counter attack, using the time stone to see this!And if he had seen this and known that he will be killed he would have ... yes ... destroyed the stones as he says ... and that is a great thing ... but ... still he would have known that past his death ... the Avengers will travel back in time and get the stones again, snapped back everyone into existence again and killed him for second time in the present time ... he would have known thisBut when I saw this film, Thanos was deliberately limited in ability even when having all the stones in his possession to make the avengers win ... which is very wrong.Second Weakness ... If Doctor Strange only saw one possibility of winning this, so would Thanos see that too and found a way to secure his goal. There is no way you can have all the stones in your hand and still not see the whole future ahead of you. Thanos would have known everything about the happen after the first snap, you just don't retire knowing your plan will fail ...This "reality" is very bare and I don't understand why it wasn't dealt with in the film ... this made me honestly dislike the film, the first one (infinity war) had great plot points, but this was majorly lacking due to what I have written about.I honestly felt like giving it a 3/10, infinity war I gave it a 9/10

First of all...... I must clarify that I'm not Biased towards any production. I like superhero movies and I enjoy watching them. But above all...... What's most important for me is the storyline of the movie and the absolute justification of the story portrayed. No doubt Endgame was the most awaited and most ambitious project for MCU and the fans....... Maybe that's why it went from "great+5" to "disappointing-6" by the end of the movie.**SPOILERS**The story had the most simple and obvious start to the story with Captain Marvel bringing Tony Stark and Nebula to Earth. And they rushed in showing that....... The rescue went on so quickly that it couldn't create a sense of excitement and suspense of how Tony Stark reaches Earth after being stranded mid-space..... Thus wasting all the hype created by the first Endgame Trailer.Then, just like that, they went to get Thanos at another planet and Thor finally goes for the Head...... Done...... Accepted...... And that's the end of Captain Marvel's hype created at the end of Infinity War and in Captain Marvel.Now, Avengers are broken and living quietly trying to recover from the losses...... Done...... Agreed...... Too much to take....... But why make Thor a Santa Clause.....? That was the most rated character to take on Thanos one on one........ But he was used as a Comedian in the whole movie, Drunk and Fat. Stormbreaker for opening Beer Bottles..??? Hilarious and Disappointing.Coming to Hulk, or Professor Hulk........ Good character..... And equally powerful to take on Thanos.......but he was buried all the time under the debris....... That's where the character got wasted. No proper use of an important character.Clint and Natasha....... Ok......
Went on Vormir...... One sacrifices life to get the stone...... Ok...... Accepted....... That was the only thing Black Widow had to do in movie...... Atleast they used Clint Barton in a proper way this time.Scott Lang all of a sudden becomes a science genius who talks about Time Travel and Quantum Physics. And seriously....... A mouse rescues Antman from Quantum Realm...??No words for Thanos, Steve Rogers and Tony Stark because these three were the only ones who got proper screen time and focus.But Time Travel and Timelines...? They hell lot messed it up despite saying they'll restore it after everything is over. Cmon..., Thanos and his Army came from past to the present and Died. That means New York, Ultron, Civil War, Infinity War and all of it....... That must not happen at all....... And how did they restore the Tesseract and Sceptre after using the Stones, to put it back in the past........And it seems there were two Steve Rogers all this time, since the present one went back and stayed. Again.... Sentimental touch......And why create an emotional drama by killing Tony Stark....... The character on which the whole MCU is dependent........ Could have easily retired him to a quiet life in the woods........The final Battle is the only thing that looked worthwhile with the exceptions of lesser Thor and Hulk vs Thanos....... And now out of nowhere Captain Marvel comes back to take some credits and lead the girls gang of MCU........Dr. Strange gets special appearanceIts just an entertainer for the MCU Fans....... But if you try finding logic in the storyline....... I think you'll be just as confused as I was after watching the movie. Go for it to complete the MCU journey and 3D Action Experience. Its still a long way to beat "The Dark Knight Trilogy"

I've grown up with the MCU with Iron Man coming out when I was 5 years old. I love this series and it's sad that the main saga is over but I expected a bit more. I gave Infinity War a 9/10 because of its amazing pace, fun characters and unexpected gut-wrenching ending, but this film has sluggish and inconsistent pacing, ruined character arcs (like Hulk as in IW he was afraid to even show himself but now they sorted everything out... Off screen), and a very predictable story and ending. I'm not even joking when I say that (even though my prediction was slightly different) my prediction to the film was extremely accurate to the films events.To conclude, I watched Infinity War 3 times in cinemas and who knows how many times on Blu-Ray, but I've only seen Endgame once and have no intention of seeing it again anytime soon: I liked it, but was overall disappointed.

Spoilers follow...
As somebody who has watched and enjoyed superhero movies since the first Superman movies starring Christopher Reeve, Dark Knight Trilogy, all the way to the first Avengers this movie does not live up to A-grade standards.First the good:
1. Impressive visual effects
2. Great acting by Robert Downey and the entire castThe bad:
1. The solution to their woes--time travels seems like an idea from Harry Potter rather rather than a superhero movie. Instead of what it was supposed to be ...super heroes working together to intelligently plan and execute a way to beat Thanos...against all odds....with the risk of certain death, what we have as a solution is.... to go back in time and avoid facing Thanos altogether. How unheroic! And what a convenient device to avoid solving the problem created in Infinity War! With this precedent we should not believe that any superhero can die, since it will be possible to correct any death by time travel with the effort of the flick of a switch. Didn't know being a superhero could be so easy!2. Is this supposed to be a war? How is it that we have a record number of heroes/aliens/explosions in this "war" and yet not a single casuality...or barely a scratch on the good side. Are these aliens totally inept? And if by some miracle any of these heroes actually dies...no problem...you can always go back in time and voila!...problem solved. By the way, the unnatural way Iron Man died does not count because Robert Downey is clearly tired of this role, and just like Harrison Ford in Force Awakens, probably just asked to be killed off abruptly. Let me bet that if Robert Downey was willing to continue, no way will they kill this money maker!So in conclusion, while this movie is supposed to be a superhero war movie, the magical use of time travel to solve all the world's ills is not the kind of short cut instant formula solution that make good movies. The fact that they have a war with no casualties on the "good" side confirms the bad storytelling of this very long big budget movie. Perhaps Disney can focus less on selling more toys and have a story with more realism that follows natures laws.

I've never been a super fan of Superhero movies. Having said that have seen most of the marvel films. The one takeaway from Avengers Endgame is that it is an extremely ambitious piece of film making. It's unusual that so many of the actors and artists who many people have come to idolize over the years should come together in a film.The film starts five years after Infinity Wars ended. Not going to include any spoilers, but there's a good part of the opening half of the film spent looking into the devastating consequences of Infinity Wars which are very script/character driven. Not surprisingly the second half of the film is very much action based and the 3 hours running time fairly fizzes along. Although it isn't perfect Endgame is definitely one of the best Superhero movies I've watched and lived up to expectations.

Dear, dear directors,Please stay away from time travel in your movies. It is guaranteed that the consistency of your story line is fraud. Always.Don't get me wrong: I liked this movie. I really did. But one can't help thinking all kind of scenarios as to: what if?Avengers Endgame seriously defers from all different time movies. An older Nebula kills a younger version of herself. There's a reason why all other time movies ever made consider this impossible... because of some logic in timelines.OK, so in Endgame the theory is that time lines are not connected. You can go back in time, mess the timeline up as far as killing your younger self and still return to your own future like nothing happened. I think it's a kinda lame way to look at time travel, but OK, theoretically possible.But then explain this to me: in the end, Captain America travels back to put all the infinity stones back in their timelines. He does not return using the time machine, but still ends up in the actual timeline as an old man. I'm sorry, but that is inconsistent.Another inconsistency, unavoidable by all time travel movies... how far back do you actually have to travel to meet your own self? It's pretty common to travel back years and find a younger version of yourself. But what if you travel back just one second... will there be two versions of you for the rest of your time line?Time travel is just messy. I don't even want to start about all the time lines that get messed up by Endgame: no Age of Ultron, no Vision, no Scarlet Witch, etc.The last comment I have on this movie is the inconsistency of the power that these superheroes have. In Infinity War, Thor beats up Thanos even when Thanos has all the infinity stones. Iron Man fights Thanos better on Titan than in Endgame on earth. Seriously, without any infinity stones Thanos beats Captain America, Iron Man, Thor and later Captain Marvel who basically flies through armored ships... but can't flight straight through Thanos.I might be over analyzing, I know.Last mayor inconsistency: Thanos is able to get hundreds of people from 2012 to present day using the time machine. The Avengers don't even consider this option... they need to get all infinity stones first to undo the snap. Might it be an idea to bring back about 10-20 key people first and THEN go after the stones?Oh, and nobody got the idea at the end of the movie to ask Captain America, who was going back anyways to put the stones back in their timelines, to bring a version of Natasha, Tony and Vision back with him? I mean... this worked for Gamorra.... she is the version of another timeline...Conclusion: time travel messes up story lines BIG time. Please stay away from them. Find other means to turn things around...Thanks for reading.

The first half of the movie have some slow and boring scenes, not an end game type movie, missing action and the power start, the second half and the last 40 minutes marvels best, can watch multiple times only for thanos

First off what is it with Disney making everything so generic and bland. Sorry but you have a franchise so big with so many characters that "vanished" and what do you do with them... well not to give it away but Cher's song comes to mind, why because that's the only thing you can do silly! The only problem with it is it takes the non vanished ones like 45 minutes to figure this out. The rest of the movie is spend getting the stones with of course the epic battle in the end. I don't have a problem with this as it is a typical big budget movie that will probably break even more records through the course of time, or at least until the next big movie comes up in this crowded theaters. What I liked was the part of Thanos and his daughters, yes it slowed the pacing down a dat but it was emotional and meaningful. I also liked the humor, except for the Hulk being half Banner and half Hulk... it's like the executive is ok just throwing out what it means to be these various characters. The ending was also sad saying goodbye to some of the characters... some died others passed the torch to other ones which is where I have a problem. Sorry but for some it's regrettable to have a character be replaced since they really didn't need to (Captain America living a full life only to return a old man and passing the torch... with more of those red viles needed to turn back time couldn't he just go back in time again and remain CA?) all I can think of why they would do this is for being PC and/or to save Disney 20 million bucks a picture. There were other PC moments in the film, like in the epic battle there has to be a girl power moment out of the blue and it goes nowhere ... once again it's fine just too obvious. It's not a bad movie but also not worth the universal praise it is receiving either. I like the marvel movies and this one is no exception. The story just needed a bit more than turning back time and finding the stones. There are a lot of what happens next in the next films and I hope they do other things with Marvel post Stan Lee.

After a decade, finally came the conclusion of the Avengers and in the mere mortals we waited for so long, and this is the movie they deliver? I expected more. The Avengers Infinite War is a cool movie, however it is not perfect. But the Endgame ruin things with these facts:

It wasn't bad, bu it's a simple action cliche, with humor, without drama or deep message. What special about infinity war, is the conflict. The villain is not all evil. He wants to create a better world for everyone to thrive. Infinity war ends with a dissonance, and many viewers, me included asked themselves - maybe he is right. Endgame starts with a simple answer - the world is a mess after Thanos actions. I think the world can thrive even with half of the population, but here right from the beginning the answer is simple. Endgame switched from the attempt to make the bad guy have deep character, into a clear message: "Thanos is all bad". Well this message continues through the entire movie, and I hate the fact they ruined the deep complex villain character, with a "want to destroy all, including his comrades " boring villain.

I wanted this movie to be good, no great. But it just wasn't. Plot holes galore, needless scenes, and terrible pacing riddle this movie like buckshot. I so wanted this movie to be good that I went back to see it again. And as I sit here with my Captain America t shirt still on from the night before, I feel the need to vent some honest nerd rage.First and foremost, time travel is the biggest, dumbest McGuffin (a tool you use to forward the plot) ever. For one thing it's tricky, you don't want paradoxes and you to mess with the time stream continuem. But they did. The movie opens with Thanos, who is at this point the most powerful, knowledgeable person in exsistence. So he destroys the stones so no one can undo what he's done. Well, if you had all the infinity stones you would be aware of multiple timelines and universes and destroying the gems in this timeline is utterly futile. And while we are taking about Thanos, he is way more one dimensional and dumbed down than he was in "Infinity War".Secondly, time travel!! Captain America goes back and encounters his past self. Past Cap says that it's Loki but when their shields collide, Past Cap should realize something is afoot. If it was Loki, the illusion should have shattered, yet both shields rebound after impact and fall into the abyss. When did Future Cap get his shield back and if he didn't, wouldn't we have a Past Cap moving forward with 2 shields. Again, time travel is a tricky thing.Thirdly, didn't Doctor Strange have the time stone the entire time?! He could have went back and changed any number of possibilities. I suppose by oath he was barred from using it even if it meant saving half the universe.I'm going to stop counting at this point.But hey, don't give the gauntlet to the only god you have on the team because he's been drinking for five years. No give it to Robert Downy Jr. because he's tired of being Iron Man and that makes sense. Also, how many times do you need to snap the gauntlet?! One to bring everyone back and another to dust Thanos? Why couldn't have been one snap? (Answer: contract negotiations)Did the Hulk smash anything other than keys on a keyboard?And finally, no after credit anything????? I mean, if you count your average comic book fan, at matinee prices we spent on average $220 just to see this in theatres, not including dvds, blu rays, and other merch. The very least you could've done was a thank you for watching or in the infamous words of Stan Lee "Nuff said".

The premise is good, the idea and concept are great, all the materials are historically foretold, but they put too many side stories on screen and making the movie too much about nothing important. This movie started to become alive again once the battle started.I would suggest a 30-to-40-minute cut would be great and release this theatrical version as extended version on BluRay would be better. If DCs BvS and Justice League required extended story scenes, this has way too many unnecessary scenes.However, I'm glad they ended it, however they don't have the "WOW" (shocking/surprising/exciting climatic) moments that usually ended a long sagas. Instead, they have a throwdown battle. At least the dramatic ending was 'proper' for retiring old celebrated heroes of the series.

Pros:
top notch cinematic, over the top action, nice concept of time travel.Cons:
chaotic scenes with so many characters, forced cringe moments.

This movie was great for what it was. A closing of the book that is the MCU's first 10 years. It isn't going to satisfy everyone. It had funny moments, it had touching moments, it had moments of dread and desperation. Character development and closing of their arcs is far more important than visual appeal and action. Especially when you have to allow beloved characters to pass on the torch to the future of the MCU. People need to wait until explanations about certain decisions in the movie come to light. When people have watched the movie again and watched the director commentary along with it, then you can give a meaningful review.

Go ahead and watch the trailers for Avengers: Endgame, they won't give anything major away. It's amazing for a huge movie to be so self-aware of itself, as well as, the movie genres that they're overtly borrowing from. The minor characters or those not even in Avengers: Infinity War, step up and help set up huge sequences that are highly entertaining and actually answer questions. Avengers: Endgame acknowledges every aspect of the characters emotions in their previous MCU film's and succeeds in the most Meta way possible.Ant-Man is a major reason for this. It's no spoiler to say that he's in the film as he produces some of the biggest laughs from the trailer of him ringing the bell at the Avenger's front gate. It's Paul Rudd's wry jokes, quick timing and fish out of water facial expressions that really assist things.The pacing of Avengers: Endgame is amazing and not for the reasons you might think. It's brilliantly paced, but it throws the entire formula and how MCU films are done on their head. Battle, loss, battle, loss, humor and then victory, take those ingredients, shake well and you've got a loose description of some average superhero films.If Avengers: Infinity War left you feeling betrayed and bummed out, I feel you. Avengers: Endgame more than makes up for any ill feelings that it caused. I see why they played it the way they did, and doing so any other way would've cheapened the film, watered down the MCU and made it all disposable. It is also worth noting that the film balance lots of humor with the drama, all the while putting it in a nice bow with stones.What we're left with is a 10 year opus that spans more arcs than Lord of the Rings and encapsulates it all in a perfect manner. Granted, they will still make many MCU films, this is not their swan song. However, there is a victory lap feeling about Avengers: Endgame. It respects the fans, adds to the dramatic elements, answers questions that fans have wondered about and plants a couple new seeds to grow on.Is Avengers: Endgame OK for children? If your child has seen any MCU film then they'll be OK with this. The film has fair number of bad words, but the violence is on par with what younger fans are accustomed to. For example, there isn't any one instance that's as graphic as when the monster ate the businessman in Shazam!, but there are sustained action sequences that might test those 8 years old who haven't seen an MCU movie before.

The trailers to this film are completely misleading. It painted a bleak, inevitable outcome for the surviving heroes after Thanos's devastating snap that left the whole universe in ruins.It goes into a completely different direction than I originally expected. For one thing, it's much funnier than I thought.
It's also nothing like Infinity War. It's basically a mix of many other marvel movies all wrapped into one epic heist film.Its lengthy time run does get a bit problematic at times, but by the time the climactic battle sequence comes by the end, you forget all about it. Those who had been disappointed or despondent by Infinity War will rejoice when seeing this one.The film is a true testament to sacrifice, love and loss. Obviously I laughed, I cried and I clapped. This is truly cinematic history.

The tech side of this film is stunning. The acting is top notch but the story is convoluted... yes even for a comic book film....SPOILERS AHEADkilling black widow was the biggest risk this film took. Capt turning into the wielder of Thor's hammer was cool but predictable as was the demise of Tony. Hulk being soy hulk was annoying but definitely not a deal breaker and seeing some old favs was cool.Biggest problem was it felt like I could see what was going to happen 45 minutes before it did (with black widows death being the exception... I thought it would be Clint). I enjoyed to over the top end battle with a few exceptions... the femvengers being jammed throats was cringy as heck (I realize Disney pushes cultural marxism but that was pure cringe)... we love the characters for who they are, not gender. With that said, Iron pepper had my eyes rolling to the point I saw my feeble little mammal brain and inside of my nose...Good points: Tony dying and Capt (America, not the gender studies) getting to grow old. Not all endings need to be happy was something I truly agree within this film. Now I can put the MCU to rest for good... not great but good.P.S. seeing Thanos blast carol danvers to space was oddly satisfying

I had very high hopes for this movie when it started at one minute past midnight on the day of release. It just took so long to get started (for me).
Now let me just say I LOVE MARVEL MOVIES I've seen them all at the cinema , I've bought all the DVD'S and I know that Endgame will be the last we'll see of certain stars in the MCU but this film was too long and in some parts downright depressing.
Captain Marvel did not get enough air time for me, neither did Black Widow and The Hulk looked a lot smaller than he did in Ragnarok, these are just some of my observations and I've many, many more.
The best part of the movie was the Battle at the end, it just a shame it took so long to get there.

I'm among those people, who normally don't engage in writing reviews. But this time I really have and want to. I rewatched the infinity-saga prior to Engame's release and there couldn't have been a better ending to it then the one it got. It really has been an epic ride and I feel privileged to have been able to be a part of it. Though only being a spectator, I feel connected to these characters, they are like long know friends. Endgame is the epic and monumental end to the saga which began over a decade ago. And oh it is more then worthy to be the last milestone on this incredible journey. I went through so many emotions watching this, joy, pride, happiness, sorrow and a sense of being alive and what it means to be human. Just watch it, you'll see what I mean, I really don't promise too much. It's truely hard to say goodbye to so many beloved characters, but they get the ending they deserve and will always be the franchise's core. Thank you for this amazing journey Marvel.
Time travel can't be done. what it cost if we use to create multiverse? endgame not explain it at all, what it cost of multiverse. I prefer time travel in x-men universe, that's more accepted.

Woah!...what can I say? This is the movie event of the year, if not this decade! It Caps (pardon the pun) of 11 years of MCU joy and sends some characters out with a bang! Literally EVERYONE thats ever been in a Marvel movie is in this thing.
It is absolutely hilarious in places, with standout comedy performances going to Thor and Hulk, who had me cracking up, Thor especially with his 'new look' lol
It was as I expected it to be for the first act, slow going and moody, with a massive sense of loss after the 'snap' with wiped out half the universe.
But you dont care, your just reeling from these characters who have lost so much, and feeling their pain. They lost big time! And they know it!
It's very unexpected in one aspect though, as you'll see, when they catch up with a certain villain very early on, and your like..woah..ok!?I'm not gonna harp on, just gonna say you'll laugh, you'll cry, you'll be thrilled and entertained for 3hrs and a minute. I need to go and see it at least twice more to fully take it in, as I'm still reeling from the midnight screening.Bravo to the Russo bros, I take my hat of to you both and say thank you for a movie event I'll remember for a long time to come. Take a bow guys, you deserve it soooo much.

I went into the cinema expecting to have at least as a great time as infinity war, but came out unimpressed. The path of restoring the stones took too long, time travel just too easy an escape to explain things, captian marvel just too powerful it's boring.

I was so excited for this movie just like so many others, but I was seriously underwhelmed throughout. People said there was a single 4 minute lull in the middle of the movie, however, it felt like a good majority of the movie was nothing but lulls and filler. I really hoped for this movie to be so good, but by the end I was left scratching my head. It was so disappointing, especially for a Marvel movie, and I felt very let down by the series that I've grown up with. There are many unresolved plot holes throughout the whole movie that leaves me wondering how it made it to production with plot holes and mistakes this bad. I believe there was lots of lousy, careless writing and production on account of the production team resting on their laurels of being Marvel and the hype of the movie. On top of all these mistakes, there were definitely points of politicizing gender bias at points where it didn't make sense to put it. Honestly, that was totally unnecessary and highly detracting from the already poorly made movie. I was also disappointed by the use, or better stated misuse, of characters, such as Captain Marvel. For all the hype that was brought up about her, I misunderstood all of it. I never saw her movie, and told it was unnecessary for the avengers timeline. After watching, it was correct. She was used in only two points as a deus ex machina and nothing else. Using a character, especially as powerful as she was for nothing but a deus ex machina is a very amateurish level of writing. It could've been so much better for an ending to the MCU story, but I was so let dow and keep wishing it were better.

Pretty sure Robert Downey Jr got his lines wrong. What he clearly meant to say is back to the future is clearly a way better depiction of time travel. Long gone are the days where movies had real emotional empathy and believability, they must have got washed up in the shores of time. Great Scott, if only we could go back to when these film had tangible sets and characters with substance and weight. This movie begins where infinity war left off with half the population doing a disappearing act, involuntarily of course. Our main protagonist Iron Man is lost in space and somehow found out of nowhere with very little reason. The new kid on the block has a talent for picking out people from space with, with her arms, or so it would appear. Eat your heart out superman!! Yet we are willing to let most this go, the task of expanding the universe further seems exhausting enough. With a barrel load of character to tackle not even three hours can save this mess. Maybe because they have to stick to their Hollywood Marvel formula and get the routine thirty minute, am I watching a kid play Mortal Kombat? Battle scene in!! The only thing missing is the vintage finish him voice at the finale. Reminence of the battle scene in "ready player one" springs to mind. Don't misinterpret me I don't mind a well built up epic conclusion but unfortunate this felt like a reversal of what had already materialised in the previous outting. As far as character and acting goes our main bunch handled themselves to the usual standard. We had nice chemistry wisecracks and charisma throughout the film and with regards to pacing it's a little slow to start off with. It's a good thirty to forty five of we're getting the band back together!! Without giving too much away it is a very linear one dimension story but still packs a bit of a punch with some humour and emotion from time to time. With regards to empathy I felt more for the characters towards the end than in the early stages. I felt like they failed at the start where you should feel really sad for the friends they lost but they all seemed to have moved on five years on. Scarlett Johansson's character was the only one who made me feel like it had actually happened. Overall it was an average finish, nothing to go to mad about.

No one goes to see a comic book movie expecting to see an art house film. It happens sometimes but it is not the normal. What you expect to see is a fun movie with some philosophical concept and some emotional depth, comic books were never just about the action. So is this a great film? I don't care. Watching it I never stopped to think if there are plot holes or if the cinematography is good, I just enjoyed it. And enjoyed almost everything about it. The Russo brothers are not the new Goddard or the new Bergman (or even the new Spielberg) but they are talented and intellectual people, they had a goal and they delivered by not only doing fan service but also story service. The MCU has a great future.So, is it a great film? Comparing it with cinematic masterpieces I could give it a 6-7/10. Comparing it with other blockbuster movies I could give it a 12/10, it's that good...

Avengers: Endgame
After the devastating events of Avengers: Infinity War (2018), the universe is in ruins. With the help of remaining allies, the Avengers assemble once more. After seen it hard to say but Marvel disappointed to not used their greatest villain in the endgame.
The film is about undo the "SNAP" that's it! Nothing else. For this, 3 hours is too long to do nothing. beginning of the movie (the Clint part) was so perfect and then couple of minutes was so fast I don't know why they'd cut so many scenes, completely unsatisfied.
The creation of aftermath was good. The middle part of the movie was boring cause they'd spend so much time on some unusual moments, funny moments in very serious situation, time travel plot holes, ruined the most valuable character Thor, Banner and Thanos. So, almost 2 hours I hadn't seen any villain I thought that marvel conclude Thanos's story but they didn't and also, they haven't used all the infinity stones individually. only they'd used for the "SNAP".
Last hour of the film. well first 30 minutes overall average cause we know this is the endgame the last film of phase 3 so, I guess it would have been perfect if everyone hadn't come. So, calling everyone's back that ruined everything. And then Tony's Funeral I guess the best sequence in the film.
The character development of the Tony, Captain, and Hawkeye was good. These characters were so special cause of their unique way. Favourite scene sequence was Tony's funeral. Had so much intense. Cinematography and Directing was good then the infinity war but not that much good then the first avengers. Overall wanted more, even far from perfect.
So, I give 6/10 because of,
The movie was too long. And music wasn't interesting.
Poor treatment of Thor, Hulk/Banner.
Completely ruined Thanos.
Re-introduction of vanished Avengers.
Poor screenplay.
Lack of captain marvel.
Time travel plot holes.

Maybe my expectations were too high but in the end this move was just OK. It isn't bad - and it is a must see if you are invested in the Marvel Universe - but it isn't great. Maybe it gets lost in trying to include too many characters or maybe is Disney trying to be PC and intentionally make it try to appeal to too many people but in the end it made it less interesting. It has its crowd cheering moments and is epic - but when the big spoilers happen I almost didn't care. Hopefully Marvel can reboot with the X-men and Fantastic 4 because the current group has run its course.

I gave infinity war a 4 out of 10 for a variety of reasons. But the main reasons were that the ending wasn't conclusive even for an MCU film, and the villain's goal seemed extremely contrived. His goal even seems ridiculous to me within the realm of typical superhero villain motives.I felt annoyed that no hero character ever tried to intellectual argue with Thanos about his plans. No one ever asked why Thanos he couldn't try to use the infinity stones to make more resources rather than fewer inhabitants. Or why he felt that every planet was identical to his home planet in needing half their inhabitants to die, given the evidence of each planet have distinct differences problems.Nevertheless, I like the story idea of half of the main characters dying and needing to be saved by the other half. I just felt that a more unhinged villain or an accident could have been a better excuse for such a mishap occurring and needing to be resolved in Endgame. I was especially annoyed at the point when they nearly had the glove off Thanos before losing focus.But luckily Endgame is about solving the problems of Infinity War, and that story is a lot more fun and acceptable. Even if it involves time travel, at least none of the characters act buzzards like the physics of this alternate world.Endgame is the longest MCU film at just over 3 hours. But for me it only feels slow in a couple places.The story also provides some great reminiscing by reuniting all of the original Avengers and eliminating quite a bit of the clutter of so many characters within the last film. Only Ant-Man, Rocket, and Nebula really join the original 6 Avengers characters for the bulk of this film. The film's smaller cast allows for some more focus and growth for Tony Stark, Thor, Hulk, Hawk-eye and others as they each deal with their new normal differently.Even though the film turns out to be a time-travel movie, it also doesn't try to be like the typical time travel movie where changing the past impacts the present and future.The writers use time-travel more as an opportunity to scavenge things from the past and bring them to the present. It's sort of like the past is an alterable mirror reality they they discovered how to interact-with. This does lead to one annoyance for. The writers seem to disregard this narrative near the end when they decide that they must return the stones to where they took them. But overall I excuse this inconsistency because the sequence where they go back in time is very fun and provides for an interesting unexpected conclusion in the end.Like other Avengers movies the dialogue is often funny and the cinematography, music and acting are great.Overall I also given the film bonus points for really being a different kind of action movie then I ever thought I'd ever see. And I appreciate them deciding to not feel obliged to keep all of the characters alive forever. I like even good epic stories to eventually have some endings and conclusions. And the writers seemed to understand that in endgame.Overall it's a great ride. And I imagine if it's watched immediately after Infinity War it might make both films collected average about a 7 out of 10. I just with the infinity war would have been as good as Endgame. That would have really been something special.
I mean it's okay to not like a movie but seriously 1 star reviews do not change the fact that avengers endgame despite its flaws is still an incredible achievement.

Nevertheless, Endgame was a spectacular ending to the MCU (the first generation at least). In my opinion, a sure fire contender for top 3 MCU films so far

There was so much hype about this movie. The social media made a good deal of fuzz about the ticket records it broke, its length etc, etc.To start with the obvious: It's not a bad Marvel Movie. But it's surely not the best. Regarding the script and the pace, I think it reminds me something like Avengers 2 and Thor 2 and that's not the best movies Marvel made.To me, Thor 3 is the best movie of all Marvel Universe, because it has a super good balance between action, dialogs, script, and humor. You never felt bored, you never felt you knew what's coming.On Endgame, sometimes I felt bored. It was a combination of medicre editing, script or acting. For example, fat Thor joke wasn't halve as good as bad haircut Thor. The scenes that should produce laughs, were between average and good.Although 3 hours long, it failed to show the extension of misery the planet has fallen into. In the opening scenes they easily kill Thanos, next scene misery, third scene hope, fourth scene Stark rejects the idea of time travel, next scene he finds the solution, next scene, the machine is ready. It's the very same Tony Stark that on Iron Man 2 spend half a movie trying to figure out how to create a new element.Time travel movies are always problematic because no matter how much mumbo jumbo terminology you add, the truth is that no matter how the heroes avoid to interact or change the future, their own existance on the past will change their universe. So, Endgame can laugh about Hot Tub Time Machine, but the truth is, it is still a HTTM movie.. ;DAlso, it's disappointing to continiously upgrade Thor's powers and on the final battle scenes, to take them back without a proper explanation. Thor easily defeated a Thanos that was on the maximum of his powers using the Infinity Gauntled on Infinity War, but on Endgame, he's unable to beat him even without Thanos having full power! That's silly.Yes it's a huge movie and even with 30 second cameos from top actors like Robert Redford or Michael Douglas you should need 1 hour for all characters but in the end, it's not about how many people you will squeeze into the movie. It's about how you will build a good pace with balanced action and humor.Maybe it's about the fact that everybody pretty much knew how things would end while on other movies like Thor 3, things were a bit more chaotic. Maybe it's because there wasn't much time about showing the details of a 5 year period. Maybe it was the fact that the first memory that jumps into my mind every time I recall the movie is Black Widow standing on a desk and coordinating x-avengers. Maybe is the fact that Thor from an arrogant young person, became super-strong in 5 movies (Thor 1,2,3, Avengers 1,2) and then, back to mediocre again. Maybe is the fact that Hulk was portrayed like the Beast from X-Men now. Maybe it was because we never got answers from the previous movie, like what Loki meant when he talked about the sun rising again, or why Hulk refused to help Banner. Even on this movie, Hawkeye becoming a renegade, makes no sense. All heroes that presented a second chance (Stark, Thor, Hawkeye) react like "Nah, I will pass" instead of be super-excited about it. I know 5 years passed, but the movie fails to show how this period changed our heroes.Thanos final fight on Infinity War, much inferior to that of Endgame.
Humor much much inferior to Thor3.Of course it is not a bad movie, but it could epic - and despite all those Anchorman cameos, it's not. But I guess, when you have limited time to repeat a wordwide success, surely you will have fails now and then.Endgame was destined to be an epic ending. It was. But only 8 out of 10.

Before I start, I rated Infinity war two stars higher. I thought it was very good movie.This movie has many good moments, but there are way too many didn't-have-to-be-there moments along side them. Too many characters, to much time devoted to each one. It's a series of vignettes tied loosely together by a outrageously irrational plot.But in the end, when I think about it, it was the largely pointless and depressing exposition that rattles on for a good hour that really killed it for me. I seriously almost walked out.I'm not going into plot specifics because they simply won't stand the scrutiny of logic, but I will mention that Captain Marvel seems to be there just to advertise that franchise and she comes and goes for no apparent reason. There's another product placement so obvious that I groaned out loud, along with several people around me. This is a movie driven by too many concerns other than simply making a really good film.If you loved it, god bless you. I found it maudlin and bouyed only by a lot of very, very good acting and interesting characters. If that's enough for you, say no more.I will say that if the point was to end my interest in future Marvel movies, it pretty much did the job.
Although a huge movie it still made time for small character work and conclusions to the smallest of details left in the MCU. A perfect finish!

It doesn't deserve a rating below 10 and hats off to Russo brothers they are awesome.

Warning - SpoilersOverall, Endgame is a good but not great superhero movie. Marvel did something I never thought possible, they made a boring movie. I understand it is difficult to maintain continuity over 20+ movies and introduce new characters and plots along the way and Marvel has done a phenomenal job with the MCU. This culminated in the excellent Infinity War which I loved and have watched 5 or 6 times now. What made IW great was the energy they were able to maintain while weaving together different characters and stories. It was funny, emotional, and had lots of great action.Here are some things I liked about Endgame:
Tony's ending seemed like a fitting conclusion for this phase. He essentially started the MCU way back in 2008 and his sendoff here was a nice tribute to his character. I didn't feel like he needed to die and thought he would serve as a father figure and guide for Peter Parker in future Spiderman movies but can see how Marvel went in this direction.Captain America living but altering his past seemed like a choice he would make given how he seemed to have no place in the present or future. He lived in the past and was a relic of a bygone era. The ending was a bit schmaltzy but I liked him passing on the shield to Sam. One issue, so Cap can suddenly wield Mjolnir and summon lightning?What I didn't like:Runtime and pacing! Ok, so they wanted to make a 3 hour movie, fine, I love Return of the King and all. If you do that, you have to keep the energy up! I felt like Marvel didn't know what to do with the characters that survived the snap. Without most of the Guardians, Black Panther, Dr. Strange, Spidey, etc., the focus was on minor characters like Black Widow, Hawkeye, and Nebula. Did we really need to see Hawkeye mope around for 180 minutes?? Strange move for Marvel to snap most of the newer (and funnier!) heroes and not bring them back until the last 30 minutes of the movie. These seemed more like cameo appearances to me. It produced a lot of forced comedy which no one in my theater laughed at. I even missed Ebony Maw and the CoT who really fleshed out the bad guys in IW. Without these interactions which made IW so great, the movie dragged!Thor and Hulk. It's an absolute disgrace to turn Thor into a Jim Carrey impersonation of Jim Morrison for most of this movie. I chuckled when he is introduced but the joke became old fast. He is one of the best developed characters in Ragnarok and IW because he has so much emotional baggage regarding Thanos and they ruined him here. In the first 120 minutes he makes no contribution to the plot, as if he is just a drunk frat boy hung over in the corner. Professor Hulk was okay but they could have spent at least 10 minutes of the first 2 hours showing us how he made that balance happen. Wouldn't that have been cool?? We are first introduced to him in a diner dabbing for some kids taking selfies, pretty lame.Time travel and hand waving. Okay so time travel is how they figure out how to defeat Thanos and undo the snap. I'll suspend belief a bit on how it works but did Tony really figure it out after running a few models in his basement in 1 day?? I won't even get into the altered timelines and whether or not you change the future by changing the past!Thanos was written so well in IW, he had a clear plan and was shown as a sometimes conflicted villain. Here he just decides to destroy everything because the survivors couldn't let go of the past 5 years later. No discussion of balance, just a one note villain.Captain Marvel. So we have an all-powerful being who can pretty much rip through any opponent or ship but she basically says I'll see you in 2 hours instead of helping out with the time travel stuff?Not showing everyone coming back when Hulk reversed the snap. Marvel missed a huge opportunity to show Black Panther, Spidey, etc. coming back into existence!! Where were they when it happened? What year was it? To have a 3 hour movie but not include this is baffling! It would have been a huge emotional moment to show their reactions and their reunions with those that survived. They all just come walking out of portals at the same time to conveniently battle Thanos in the end. But hey, we got to see some birds come back so there's that.Overall, I expected much more content in a 3 hour movie. Not bringing back the snapped characters earlier in the movie left them out of the majority of the plot and affected the pace and energy. The great interactions between the GotG, Thor, etc. in IW were missing until the very end of this one. The movie could have easily been 2 to 2.5 hours and tightened up a lot. Also, I expected to see a new big bad guy show up at some point but that will have to wait for Phase 4 I suppose. In the end, my 9 year old loved it so I guess that's all that matters!

Infinity War is my favorite Marvel film by far. This chapter or finale felt a little flat for me. I understand it's hard to compress everything this large into a 3 hour film, I truly do. But, I felt some things were dwelled on for too long while some things were not explained well or at all. One scene was emotional for sure while others did not hit home for me. I truly feel in my heart of hearts that the plot should have gone in another direction with the ending, but I do get why it did what it did. Overall it was a decent movie that in the sense of all things completed has done that for this arch.

This is the best movie I have ever seen! This movie is such a love letter to the fans of Marvel. I have never had so much emotion drawn from me in a movie. The story is so amazing and a beautiful way to end the Marvel Infinity Saga.

A movie like this shouldn't be able to exist. A 3 hour long movie that gives a conclusion to a universe that has been building up for 11 years. A movie that seamlessly blends the directorial visions of all the directors of past films and the tones present in those films. A movie whose first act let's you see the hopelessness that the hero's we have seen for the past 10 years. But, is able to put the emotional stake and realize they actually lost. A movie that is able to be a action adventure comedy and a second act that is a fantastic heist movie. A movie that is able to make time travel make sense. The second act is fantastic a cross between 3 teams that pull off a superhero oceans 11 heist and it works perfectly. Then the final act come to the climactic end that we all wanted. When Captain America has a broken shield in one hand and then mjolnir and says "avengers assemble" absolutely the best way to give comic book fans the ending battle they deserve. A once and a generation movie that will never be topped by another superhero movie.

AVENGERS : ENDGAMEA Humongous tribute to the characters Tony Stark (Robert Downey Jr.) and Captain Steve Rogers (Chris Evans) for being a vital part in Marvel Cinematic Universe.Never seen such a huge franchise paying a proper payoff to these characters.Do not watch Endgame untill you watch all the marvel films starting from Ironman to Infinity war.First half of the movie travels at a slower pace because this flick contains a phenomenal story and character arc built for the powerpacked other half.Different dimensions of Capt'n and Thor characters were shown to the audience. Which will keep the them excited throughout the movie.Directors Russo brothers came up with an epic cinematic ending. The determination and conviction for such a complex screenplay by Christopher Markus and Stephen Mcfeely has to be appreciated.We as an audience would have presumed that this film would end in a certain way. But, there are lot other Easter eggs and jaw dropping scenes which excites us and also make us whimper.Overall, with Avengers : Endgame, there is really something that comes to an end. BTW keep your tissues handy!!
One of the best movies I've ever seen , simply EPIC , Enough said
